<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Russia</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country spanning Europe and Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Russia_(disambiguation)" title="Russia (disambiguation)">Russia (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>Â 0.824<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNHDR_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNHDR-16">[14]</a></sup><br/><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:darkgreen">very high</span></span>Â Â·Â <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">52nd</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Russian_ruble" title="Russian ruble">Russian ruble</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ruble_sign" title="Ruble sign">â½</a>) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">RUB</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a numbers in Russia">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Russia" title="Telephone numbers in Russia">+7</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:RU" title="ISO 3166-2:RU">RU</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/.ru" title=".ru">.ru</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/.%D1%80%D1%84" title=".ÑÑ">.ÑÑ</a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Russia</b> (Russian: <span title="Russian-language text"><span lang="ru">Ð Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸Ñ</span></span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">tr.</a></small> <span title="Russian-language text"><i lang="ru-Latn">Rossiya</i></span>, <small>pronouncedÂ </small><span class="IPA" lang="ru-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">[rÉËsÊ²ijÉ]</a></span>) or the <b>Russian Federation</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[c]</a></sup> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transcontinental_country" title="Transcontinental country">transcontinental country</a> spanning <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Asia" title="Northern Asia">Northern Asia</a>. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">largest country in the world</a>, covering over 17,098,246 square kilometres (6,601,670Â sqÂ mi), and encompassing one-eighth of Earth's inhabitable landmass. Russia extends across <a href="/wiki/Time_in_Russia" title="Time in Russia">eleven time zones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Russia" title="Borders of Russia">borders sixteen sovereign nations</a>, more than <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_land_borders" title="List of countries and territories by land borders">any other country</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[d]</a></sup> It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">ninth-most populous country</a> in the world and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">most populous country</a> in Europe, with a population of 146 million. The country's capital and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia_by_population" title="List of cities and towns in Russia by population">largest city</a> is <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_European_cities_by_population" title="List of European cities by population">largest city entirely within Europe</a>. <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> is Russia's cultural centre and second-largest city. Other major urban areas include <a href="/wiki/Novosibirsk" title="Novosibirsk">Novosibirsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yekaterinburg" title="Yekaterinburg">Yekaterinburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod" title="Nizhny Novgorod">Nizhny Novgorod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kazan" title="Kazan">Kazan</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavs</a> emerged as a recognisable group in Europe between the 3rd and 8th centuries CE. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medieval" title="Medieval">medieval</a> state of <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a> arose in the 9th century, and in 988 adopted <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox Christianity</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>. Rus' ultimately disintegrated, with the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a> growing to become the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>. By the early 18th century, Russia had vastly expanded through conquest, annexation, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_explorers" title="Russian explorers">exploration</a> to become the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">third-largest empire</a> in history. The monarchy was abolished following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> in 1917, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian SFSR</a> became the world's first constitutionally <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a>. Following a <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">civil war</a>, the Russian SFSR established the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> with three other <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Republics of the Soviet Union">republics</a>, as its largest and the principal constituent. The country underwent a period of <a href="/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Industrialization in the Soviet Union">rapid industrialisation</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Excess_mortality_in_the_Soviet_Union_under_Joseph_Stalin" title="Excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin">expense of millions of lives</a>. The Soviet Union played a <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">decisive role</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a> victory in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, and was a superpower and rival to the United States during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. The Soviet era saw some of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_inventions_and_technology_records" title="Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records">most significant technological achievements</a> of the 20th century, including the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sputnik" title="Sputnik">first human-made satellite</a> and the launching of the <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">first human into space</a>.
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> in 1991, the newly independent Russian SFSR renamed itself the Russian Federation. In the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/1993_Russian_constitutional_crisis" title="1993 Russian constitutional crisis">constitutional crisis of 1993</a>, a new <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Russia" title="Constitution of Russia">constitution</a> was adopted, and Russia has since been governed as a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federal</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential</a> republic. Since his <a href="/wiki/2000_Russian_presidential_election" title="2000 Russian presidential election">election</a> in 2000, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> has dominated Russia's political system and Russia has experienced <a href="/wiki/Democratic_backsliding" title="Democratic backsliding">democratic backsliding</a>, shifting into an <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian state</a>. It <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_Russia" title="International rankings of Russia">ranks low</a> in international measurements of <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Russia" title="Media freedom in Russia">freedom of the press</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Russia" title="Human rights in Russia">civil liberties</a> and has high levels of <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Russia" title="Corruption in Russia">perceived corruption</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Russia" title="Economy of Russia">Russian economy</a> is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eleventh-largest by nominal GDP</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">sixth-largest by PPP</a>. It has the world's <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">largest stockpile of nuclear weapons</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">fifth-highest military expenditure</a>. Russia's extensive mineral and <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Russia" title="Energy in Russia">energy</a> resources are the world's largest, and it is among the leading <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_producer" title="Oil producer">producers of oil</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_gas_producer" title="Natural gas producer">natural gas</a> globally. It is a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>, a member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>, <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a> and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, as well as the leading member of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">CIS</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Collective_Security_Treaty_Organization" title="Collective Security Treaty Organization">CSTO</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Union" title="Eurasian Economic Union">EAEU</a>. Russia is home to <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Russia" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Russia">30 UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Rus%27,_Russia_and_Ruthenia" title="Names of Rus', Russia and Ruthenia">Names of Rus', Russia and Ruthenia</a></div>
<p>The name <i>Russia</i> is derived from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rus%27_(name)" title="Rus' (name)">Rus'</a>, a medieval state populated primarily by the <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[15]</a></sup> However, the proper name<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too vague attribution or weasel words. (May 2022)">which?</span></a></i>]</sup> became more prominent in later history, and the country typically was called by its inhabitants "Rus land".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[16]</a></sup> This state is denoted as <i><a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a></i> after its capital city by modern <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a>. The name <i>Rus<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span></i> itself comes from the early medieval <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_people" title="Rus' people">Rus' people</a>, a group of <a href="/wiki/Norsemen" title="Norsemen">Norse</a> merchants and warriors who relocated from across the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> and founded a state centred on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Novgorod" title="Novgorod">Novgorod</a> that later became Kievan Rus'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> version of the name Rus' was <a href="/wiki/Ruthenia" title="Ruthenia">Ruthenia</a>, which was used as one of several designations for <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> regions, and commonly as a designation for the lands of Rus'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[18]</a></sup> The current name of the country, Ð Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸Ñ (<i>Rossiya</i>), comes from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine_Greek" title="Byzantine Greek">Byzantine Greek</a> designation of the Rus', Î¡ÏÏÏÎ¯Î± <i>RossÃ­a</i>Â â spelled Î¡ÏÏÎ¯Î± (<i>RosÃ­a</i> <small>pronouncedÂ </small><span class="IPA" lang="el-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[roËsia]</a></span>) in <a href="/wiki/Modern_Greek" title="Modern Greek">Modern Greek</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[19]</a></sup> The standard way to refer to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_nationality_law" title="Russian nationality law">citizens of Russia</a> is "Russians" in English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[20]</a></sup> There are two words in Russian which are commonly translated into English as "Russians"Â â one is "ÑÑÑÑÐºÐ¸Ðµ" (<i>russkiye</i>), which most often refers to ethnic RussiansÂ â and the other is "ÑÐ¾ÑÑÐ¸ÑÐ½Ðµ" (<i>rossiyane</i>), which refers to citizens of Russia, regardless of ethnicity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Russia" title="History of Russia">History of Russia</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_colonies" title="Ancient Greek colonies">Ancient Greek colonies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavs" title="Early Slavs">Early Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkic_expansion" title="Turkic expansion">Turkic expansion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Siberia" title="Prehistory of Siberia">Prehistory of Siberia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Europeans" title="Proto-Indo-Europeans">Proto-Indo-Europeans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proto-Uralic_homeland" title="Proto-Uralic homeland">Proto-Uralic homeland</a></div>
<p>The first human settlement on Russia dates back to the <a href="/wiki/Oldowan" title="Oldowan">Oldowan</a> period in the early <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a>. About 2 million years ago, representatives of <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> migrated to the <a href="/wiki/Taman_Peninsula" title="Taman Peninsula">Taman Peninsula</a> in southern Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Flint" title="Flint">Flint</a> tools, some 1.5 million years old, have been discovered in the <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[23]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dated" title="Radiocarbon dated">Radiocarbon dated</a> specimens from <a href="/wiki/Denisova_Cave" title="Denisova Cave">Denisova Cave</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Altai_Mountains" title="Altai Mountains">Altai Mountains</a> estimate the oldest <a href="/wiki/Denisovan" title="Denisovan">Denisovan</a> specimen lived 195â122,700 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[24]</a></sup> Fossils of "<a href="/wiki/Denny_(hybrid_hominin)" title="Denny (hybrid hominin)">Denny</a>", an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archaic_human" title="Archaic human">archaic human</a> hybrid that was half <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">Neanderthal</a> and half Denisovan, and lived some 90,000 years ago, was also found within the latter cave.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[25]</a></sup> Russia was home to some of the last surviving <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">Neanderthals</a>, from about 45,000 years ago, found in <a href="/wiki/Mezmaiskaya_cave" title="Mezmaiskaya cave">Mezmaiskaya cave</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first trace of a <a href="/wiki/Ust%27-Ishim_man" title="Ust'-Ishim man">early modern human</a> in Russia dates back to 45,000 years, in <a href="/wiki/Western_Siberia" title="Western Siberia">western Siberia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[27]</a></sup> The discovery of high concentration cultural remains of <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">anatomically modern humans</a>, from at least 40,000 years ago, was found at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kostyonki%E2%80%93Borshchyovo_archaeological_complex" title="KostyonkiâBorshchyovo archaeological complex">Kostyonki and Borshchyovo</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup> and at <a href="/wiki/Sungir" title="Sungir">Sungir</a>, dating back to 34,600 years agoâboth, respectively in <a href="/wiki/European_Russia" title="European Russia">western Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[29]</a></sup> Humans reached <a href="/wiki/Far_North_(Russia)" title="Far North (Russia)">Arctic Russia</a> at least 40,000 years ago, in <a href="/wiki/Mamontovaya_Kurya" title="Mamontovaya Kurya">Mamontovaya Kurya</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:322px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1372" data-file-width="3326" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg/320px-Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg/480px-Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg/640px-Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg 2x" width="320"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yamnaya_Steppe_Pastoralists.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bronze Age spread of <a href="/wiki/Yamnaya_culture" title="Yamnaya culture">Yamnaya</a> <a href="/wiki/Western_Steppe_Herders" title="Western Steppe Herders">Steppe pastoralist</a> ancestry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[31]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Kurgan_hypothesis" title="Kurgan hypothesis">Kurgan hypothesis</a> places the Volga-Dnieper region of southern Russia and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urheimat" title="Urheimat">urheimat</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Europeans" title="Proto-Indo-Europeans">Proto-Indo-Europeans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[32]</a></sup> Early <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-European migrations</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Pontic%E2%80%93Caspian_steppe" title="PonticâCaspian steppe">PonticâCaspian steppe</a> spread <a href="/wiki/Yamnaya_culture" title="Yamnaya culture">Yamnaya</a> ancestry and <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European languages</a> across large parts of Eurasia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[34]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nomadic_pastoralism" title="Nomadic pastoralism">Nomadic pastoralism</a> developed in the PonticâCaspian steppe beginning in the <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Belinskij_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Belinskij-39">[35]</a></sup> Remnants of these steppe civilizations were discovered in places such as <a href="/wiki/Ipatovo_kurgan" title="Ipatovo kurgan">Ipatovo</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Belinskij_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-Belinskij-39">[35]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sintashta" title="Sintashta">Sintashta</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mounted_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-mounted-40">[36]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arkaim" title="Arkaim">Arkaim</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Pazyryk_burials" title="Pazyryk burials">Pazyryk</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[38]</a></sup> which bear the earliest known traces of <a href="/wiki/Horses_in_warfare" title="Horses in warfare">horses in warfare</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mounted_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-mounted-40">[36]</a></sup> The genetic makeup of speakers of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uralic_language_family" title="Uralic language family">Uralic</a> language family in northern Europe was shaped by migration from <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a> that began at least 3,500 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[39]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">classical antiquity</a>, the Pontic-Caspian Steppe was known as <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[40]</a></sup> In late 8th century BCE, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a> traders brought <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classical_civilization" title="Classical civilization">classical civilization</a> to the trade emporiums in <a href="/wiki/Tanais" title="Tanais">Tanais</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phanagoria" title="Phanagoria">Phanagoria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 3rd to 4th centuries CE, the <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">Gothic</a> kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Oium" title="Oium">Oium</a> existed in Southern Russia, which was later overrun by <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> Between the 3rd and 6th centuries CE, the <a href="/wiki/Bosporan_Kingdom" title="Bosporan Kingdom">Bosporan Kingdom</a>, which was a Hellenistic <a href="/wiki/Polity" title="Polity">polity</a> that succeeded the Greek colonies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup> was also overwhelmed by nomadic invasions led by warlike tribes such as the Huns and <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Avars" title="Pannonian Avars">Eurasian Avars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">Khazars</a>, who were of <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic origin</a>, ruled the lower <a href="/wiki/Volga" title="Volga">Volga</a> basin steppes between the Caspian and Black Seas until the 10th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[45]</a></sup> After them came the <a href="/wiki/Pechenegs" title="Pechenegs">Pechenegs</a> who created a large confederacy, which was subsequently taken over by the <a href="/wiki/Cumans" title="Cumans">Cumans</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kipchaks" title="Kipchaks">Kipchaks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ancestors of <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a> are among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_Slavic_peoples" title="List of ancient Slavic peoples">Slavic tribes</a> that separated from the Proto-Indo-Europeans, who appeared in the northeastern part of Europe ca. 1500â¯years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[47]</a></sup> The East Slavs gradually settled western Russia in two waves: one moving from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a> towards present-day <a href="/wiki/Suzdal" title="Suzdal">Suzdal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Murom" title="Murom">Murom</a> and another from <a href="/wiki/Polotsk" title="Polotsk">Polotsk</a> towards <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Novgorod" title="Novgorod">Novgorod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rostov" title="Rostov">Rostov</a>. From the 7th century onwards, the East Slavs constituted the bulk of the population in western Russia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[48]</a></sup> and slowly but peacefully assimilated the native <a href="/wiki/Finnic_peoples" title="Finnic peoples">Finnic peoples</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Kievan_Rus.27"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Kievan_Rus'">Kievan Rus'</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_Khaganate" title="Rus' Khaganate">Rus' Khaganate</a>; <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a>; and <a href="/wiki/List_of_tribes_and_states_in_Belarus,_Russia_and_Ukraine" title="List of tribes and states in Belarus, Russia and Ukraine">List of tribes and states in Belarus, Russia and Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kievan-rus-1015-1113-(en).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2659" data-file-width="2166" decoding="async" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Kievan-rus-1015-1113-%28en%29.png/220px-Kievan-rus-1015-1113-%28en%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Kievan-rus-1015-1113-%28en%29.png/330px-Kievan-rus-1015-1113-%28en%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Kievan-rus-1015-1113-%28en%29.png/440px-Kievan-rus-1015-1113-%28en%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kievan-rus-1015-1113-(en).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavic</a> state of <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Liubech" title="Council of Liubech">Council of Liubech</a> in 1097</div></div></div>
<p>The establishment of the first East Slavic states in the 9th century coincided with the arrival of <i><a href="/wiki/Varangians" title="Varangians">Varangians</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Vikings</a> who ventured along the waterways extending from the eastern Baltic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/From_the_Varangians_to_the_Greeks" title="From the Varangians to the Greeks">to the Black</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volga_trade_route" title="Volga trade route">Caspian</a> Seas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[49]</a></sup> According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Primary_Chronicle" title="Primary Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a></i>, a Varangian from the <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_people" title="Rus' people">Rus' people</a>, named <a href="/wiki/Rurik" title="Rurik">Rurik</a>, was elected ruler of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Novgorod" title="Novgorod">Novgorod</a> in 862. In 882, his successor <a href="/wiki/Oleg_of_Novgorod" title="Oleg of Novgorod">Oleg</a> ventured south and conquered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a>, which had been previously paying tribute to the <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">Khazars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-2"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> Rurik's son <a href="/wiki/Igor_of_Kiev" title="Igor of Kiev">Igor</a> and Igor's son <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sviatoslav_I_of_Kiev" title="Sviatoslav I of Kiev">Sviatoslav</a> subsequently subdued all local <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavic</a> tribes to Kievan rule, destroyed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khazar_Khaganate" title="Khazar Khaganate">Khazar Khaganate</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup> and launched several military expeditions to <a href="/wiki/Paphlagonian_expedition_of_the_Rus%27" title="Paphlagonian expedition of the Rus'">Byzantium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caspian_expeditions_of_the_Rus%27" title="Caspian expeditions of the Rus'">Persia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 10th to 11th centuries, Kievan Rus' became one of the largest and most prosperous states in Europe. The reigns of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_the_Great" title="Vladimir the Great">Vladimir the Great</a> (980â1015) and his son <a href="/wiki/Yaroslav_the_Wise" title="Yaroslav the Wise">Yaroslav the Wise</a> (1019â1054) constitute the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age" title="Golden Age">Golden Age</a> of Kiev, which saw <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianisation_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianisation of Kievan Rus'">the acceptance of</a> Orthodox Christianity from <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantium</a>, and the creation of the first East Slavic written <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_code" title="Legal code">legal code</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Russkaya_Pravda" title="Russkaya Pravda">Russkaya Pravda</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-3"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> The age of <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a> and decentralization had come, marked by constant in-fighting between members of the <a href="/wiki/Rurik_dynasty" title="Rurik dynasty">Rurik dynasty</a> that ruled Kievan Rus' collectively. Kiev's dominance waned, to the benefit of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal" title="Vladimir-Suzdal">Vladimir-Suzdal</a> in the north-east, the <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Republic" title="Novgorod Republic">Novgorod Republic</a> in the north, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galicia-Volhynia" title="Galicia-Volhynia">Galicia-Volhynia</a> in the south-west.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-4"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> By the 12th century, Kiev lost its pre-eminence and Kievan Rus' had fragmented into different principalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Penguin-p16_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Penguin-p16-57">[53]</a></sup> Prince <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Bogolyubsky" title="Andrey Bogolyubsky">Andrey Bogolyubsky</a> sacked Kiev in 1169 and made <a href="/wiki/Vladimir,_Russia" title="Vladimir, Russia">Vladimir</a> his base,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Penguin-p16_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-Penguin-p16-57">[53]</a></sup> leading to political power being shifted to the north-east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-5"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kievan Rus' finally fell to the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Mongol invasion of Kievan Rus'">Mongol invasion</a> of 1237â1240, which resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Kiev_(1240)" title="Siege of Kiev (1240)">sacking of Kiev</a> and other cities, as well as the death of a major part of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-6"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> The invaders, later known as <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a>, formed the state of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a>, which pillaged the Russian principalities and ruled the southern and central expanses of Russia for over two centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup> Only the Novgorod Republic escaped Mongol occupation after it agreed to pay tribute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-7"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>Galicia-Volhynia was eventually absorbed by <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Lithuania</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1025%E2%80%931385)" title="Kingdom of Poland (1025â1385)">Poland</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-8"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> while the Novgorod Republic and Vladimir-Suzdal, two regions on the periphery of Kiev, established the basis for the modern Russian nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-9"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> Led by Prince <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Nevsky" title="Alexander Nevsky">Alexander Nevsky</a>, Novgorodians repelled the invading <a href="/wiki/Swedes" title="Swedes">Swedes</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Neva" title="Battle of the Neva">Battle of the Neva</a> in 1240,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Crusades" title="Northern Crusades">Germanic crusaders</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Ice" title="Battle of the Ice">Battle of the Ice</a> in 1242.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2016" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg/220px-Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg/330px-Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg/440px-Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sergius_of_Radonezh" title="Sergius of Radonezh">Sergius of Radonezh</a> blessing <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Donskoy" title="Dmitry Donskoy">Dmitry Donskoy</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trinity_Sergius_Lavra" title="Trinity Sergius Lavra">Trinity Sergius Lavra</a>, before the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kulikovo" title="Battle of Kulikovo">Battle of Kulikovo</a>, depicted in a painting by <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Lissner" title="Ernst Lissner">Ernst Lissner</a></div></div></div>
<p>The destruction of Kievan Rus' saw the eventual rise of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a>, initially a part of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal" title="Vladimir-Suzdal">Vladimir-Suzdal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 11â20">:â11â20â</span></sup> While still under the domain of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongol" title="Mongol">Mongol</a>-<a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a> and with their connivance, Moscow began to assert its influence in the region in the early 14th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[58]</a></sup> gradually becoming the leading force in the "gathering of the Russian lands".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muscovy_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-Muscovy-63">[59]</a></sup> When the seat of the Metropolitan of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> moved to Moscow in 1325, its influence increased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup> Moscow's last rival, the <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Republic" title="Novgorod Republic">Novgorod Republic</a>, prospered as the chief <a href="/wiki/Fur_trade" title="Fur trade">fur trade</a> centre and the easternmost port of the <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">Hanseatic League</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>Led by Prince <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Donskoy" title="Dmitry Donskoy">Dmitry Donskoy</a> of Moscow, the united army of Russian principalities inflicted <a href="/wiki/List_of_conflicts_in_Eastern_Europe_during_Turco-Mongol_rule" title="List of conflicts in Eastern Europe during Turco-Mongol rule">a milestone defeat</a> on the Mongol-Tatars in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kulikovo" title="Battle of Kulikovo">Battle of Kulikovo</a> in 1380.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarlyH_46-10"><a href="#cite_note-EarlyH-46">[42]</a></sup> Moscow gradually absorbed its parent duchy and surrounding principalities, including formerly strong rivals such as <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Tver" title="Principality of Tver">Tver</a> and <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Republic" title="Novgorod Republic">Novgorod</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muscovy_63-1"><a href="#cite_note-Muscovy-63">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivan_III" title="Ivan III">IvanÂ III</a> ("the Great") finally threw off the control of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a> and consolidated the whole of northern Rus' under Moscow's dominion, and was the first Russian ruler to take the title "Grand Duke of all Rus'". After the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fall of Constantinople</a> in 1453, Moscow <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Third_Rome" title="Third Rome">claimed succession to the legacy</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" title="Eastern Roman Empire">Eastern Roman Empire</a>. IvanÂ III married <a href="/wiki/Sophia_Palaiologina" title="Sophia Palaiologina">Sophia Palaiologina</a>, the niece of the last <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine_emperor" title="Byzantine emperor">Byzantine emperor</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_XI" title="Constantine XI">ConstantineÂ XI</a>, and made the Byzantine <a href="/wiki/Double-headed_eagle" title="Double-headed eagle">double-headed eagle</a> his own, and eventually Russia's, coat-of-arms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muscovy_63-2"><a href="#cite_note-Muscovy-63">[59]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vasili_III_of_Russia" title="Vasili III of Russia">Vasili III</a> completed the task of uniting all of Russia by annexing the last few independent <a href="/wiki/List_of_tribes_and_states_in_Belarus,_Russia_and_Ukraine" title="List of tribes and states in Belarus, Russia and Ukraine">Russian states</a> in the early 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tsardom_of_Russia">Tsardom of Russia</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Moscow,_third_Rome" title="Moscow, third Rome">Moscow, third Rome</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ivan_IV_by_anonim_(18th_c.,_GIM).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="732" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="194" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Ivan_IV_by_anonim_%2818th_c.%2C_GIM%29.jpg/170px-Ivan_IV_by_anonim_%2818th_c.%2C_GIM%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Ivan_IV_by_anonim_%2818th_c.%2C_GIM%29.jpg/255px-Ivan_IV_by_anonim_%2818th_c.%2C_GIM%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Ivan_IV_by_anonim_%2818th_c.%2C_GIM%29.jpg/340px-Ivan_IV_by_anonim_%2818th_c.%2C_GIM%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ivan_IV_by_anonim_(18th_c.,_GIM).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivan_IV" title="Ivan IV">Ivan IV</a> was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Prince_of_Moscow" title="Grand Prince of Moscow">Grand Prince of Moscow</a> from 1533 to 1547, then "<a href="/wiki/Tsar" title="Tsar">Tsar</a> of <a href="/wiki/All-Russian_nation" title="All-Russian nation">All the Russias</a>" until his death in 1584.</div></div></div>
<p>In development of the <a href="/wiki/Moscow,_third_Rome" title="Moscow, third Rome">Third Rome</a> ideas, the grand duke <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivan_IV" title="Ivan IV">IvanÂ IV</a> ("the Terrible") was officially crowned the first <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia"><i>tsar</i></a> of Russia in 1547. The tsar <a href="/wiki/Promulgation" title="Promulgation">promulgated</a> a new code of laws (<a href="/wiki/Sudebnik_of_1550" title="Sudebnik of 1550">Sudebnik of 1550</a>), established the first Russian feudal representative body (the <a href="/wiki/Zemsky_Sobor" title="Zemsky Sobor">Zemsky Sobor</a>), revamped the military, curbed the influence of the clergy, and reorganised local government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muscovy_63-3"><a href="#cite_note-Muscovy-63">[59]</a></sup> During his long reign, Ivan nearly doubled the already large Russian territory by annexing the three Tatar khanates: <a href="/wiki/Khanate_of_Kazan" title="Khanate of Kazan">Kazan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Astrakhan_Khanate" title="Astrakhan Khanate">Astrakhan</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Volga" title="Volga">Volga</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[63]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Khanate_of_Sibir" title="Khanate of Sibir">Khanate of Sibir</a> in southwestern Siberia. Ultimately, by the end of the 16th century, Russia expanded east of the <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[64]</a></sup> However, the Tsardom was weakened by the long and unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Livonian_War" title="Livonian War">Livonian War</a> against the coalition of the <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Kingdom of Poland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a> (later the united <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>), the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Sweden_(1523%E2%80%931611)" title="History of Sweden (1523â1611)">Kingdom of Sweden</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Denmark%E2%80%93Norway" title="DenmarkâNorway">DenmarkâNorway</a> for access to the Baltic coast and sea trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[65]</a></sup> In 1572, an invading army of <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a> were <a href="/wiki/Russo-Crimean_Wars" title="Russo-Crimean Wars">thoroughly defeated</a> in the crucial <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Molodi" title="Battle of Molodi">Battle of Molodi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>The death of Ivan's sons marked the end of the ancient <a href="/wiki/Rurik_dynasty" title="Rurik dynasty">Rurik dynasty</a> in 1598, and in combination with the disastrous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1601%E2%80%9303" title="Russian famine of 1601â03">famine of 1601â1603</a>, led to a civil war, the rule of pretenders, and foreign intervention during the <a href="/wiki/Time_of_Troubles" title="Time of Troubles">Time of Troubles</a> in the early 17th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[67]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>, taking advantage, occupied parts of Russia, extending into the capital Moscow.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[68]</a></sup> In 1612, the Poles were forced to retreat by the Russian volunteer corps, led by merchant <a href="/wiki/Kuzma_Minin" title="Kuzma Minin">Kuzma Minin</a> and prince <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Pozharsky" title="Dmitry Pozharsky">Dmitry Pozharsky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[69]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romanov_dynasty" title="Romanov dynasty">Romanov dynasty</a> acceded to the throne in 1613 by the decision of the Zemsky Sobor, and the country started its gradual recovery from the crisis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia continued its territorial growth through the 17th century, which was the age of the <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossacks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siberia_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-Siberia-75">[71]</a></sup> In 1654, the Ukrainian leader, <a href="/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky" title="Bohdan Khmelnytsky">Bohdan Khmelnytsky</a>, offered to place Ukraine under the protection of the Russian tsar, <a href="/wiki/Alexis_of_Russia" title="Alexis of Russia">Alexis</a>; whose acceptance of this offer led to another <a href="/wiki/Russo-Polish_War_(1654%E2%80%931667)" title="Russo-Polish War (1654â1667)">Russo-Polish War</a>. Ultimately, Ukraine was split along the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">Dnieper</a>, leaving the eastern part, (<a href="/wiki/Left-bank_Ukraine" title="Left-bank Ukraine">Left-bank Ukraine</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a>) under Russian rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup> In the east, the rapid Russian exploration and colonisation of vast Siberia continued, hunting for valuable furs and ivory. <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_explorers" title="List of Russian explorers">Russian explorers</a> pushed eastward primarily along the <a href="/wiki/Siberian_River_Routes" title="Siberian River Routes">Siberian River Routes</a>, and by the mid-17th century, there were Russian settlements in eastern Siberia, on the <a href="/wiki/Chukchi_Peninsula" title="Chukchi Peninsula">Chukchi Peninsula</a>, along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amur_River" title="Amur River">Amur River</a>, and on the coast of the Pacific Ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siberia_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-Siberia-75">[71]</a></sup> In 1648, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semyon_Dezhnyov" title="Semyon Dezhnyov">Semyon Dezhnyov</a> became the first European to navigate through the <a href="/wiki/Bering_Strait" title="Bering Strait">Bering Strait</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Imperial_Russia">Imperial Russia</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1511" data-file-width="1944" decoding="async" height="241" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg/310px-Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg/465px-Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg/620px-Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Territorial_Expansion_of_Russia.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Expansion_of_Russia_(1500%E2%80%931800)" title="Expansion of Russia (1500â1800)">Expansion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Russia" title="Territorial evolution of Russia">territorial evolution</a> of the Grand Duchy of Moscow, Tsardom of Russia and Russian Empire between the 14th and 20th centuries.</div></div></div>
<p>Under <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter the Great</a>, Russia was proclaimed an empire in 1721, and established itself as one of the European great powers. Ruling from 1682 to 1725, Peter defeated Sweden in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a> (1700â1721), securing Russia's access to the sea and sea trade. In 1703, on the Baltic Sea, Peter founded <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> as Russia's new capital. Throughout his rule, <a href="/wiki/Government_reform_of_Peter_the_Great" title="Government reform of Peter the Great">sweeping reforms were made</a>, which brought significant Western European cultural influences to Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earlyimperial_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-earlyimperial-78">[74]</a></sup> The reign of PeterÂ I's daughter <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_of_Russia" title="Elizabeth of Russia">Elizabeth</a> in 1741â1762 saw Russia's participation in the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a> (1756â1763). During the conflict, Russian troops overran <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a>, reaching Berlin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[75]</a></sup> However, upon Elizabeth's death, all these conquests were returned to the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> by pro-Prussian <a href="/wiki/Peter_III_of_Russia" title="Peter III of Russia">PeterÂ III of Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">CatherineÂ II</a> ("the Great"), who ruled in 1762â1796, presided over the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Enlightenment" title="Russian Enlightenment">Russian Age of Enlightenment</a>. She extended Russian political control over the PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth and <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">annexed most of its territories into Russia</a>, making it the most populous country in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[77]</a></sup> In the south, after the successful <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_Wars" title="Russo-Turkish Wars">Russo-Turkish Wars</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, Catherine advanced Russia's boundary to the Black Sea, by dissolving the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Empire" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Empire">annexing Crimea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[78]</a></sup> As a result of victories over <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar Iran</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Persian_Wars" title="Russo-Persian Wars">Russo-Persian Wars</a>, by the first half of the 19th century, Russia also <a href="/wiki/Russian_conquest_of_the_Caucasus" title="Russian conquest of the Caucasus">conquered the Caucasus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[79]</a></sup> Catherine's successor, her son <a href="/wiki/Paul_I_of_Russia" title="Paul I of Russia">Paul</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Personality_and_reputation_of_Paul_I_of_Russia" title="Personality and reputation of Paul I of Russia">unstable and focused predominantly on domestic issues</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[80]</a></sup> Following his short reign, Catherine's strategy was continued with <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Russia" title="Alexander I of Russia">AlexanderÂ I's</a> (1801â1825) <a href="/wiki/Finnish_War" title="Finnish War">wresting of Finland</a> from the weakened Sweden in 1809,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[81]</a></sup> and of <a href="/wiki/Bessarabia" title="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> from the Ottomans in 1812.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[82]</a></sup> In North America, the Russians became the first Europeans to <a href="/wiki/Russian_America" title="Russian America">reach and colonise Alaska</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[83]</a></sup> In 1803â1806, the <a href="/wiki/First_Russian_circumnavigation" title="First Russian circumnavigation">first Russian circumnavigation</a> was made.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[84]</a></sup> In 1820, <a href="/wiki/Fabian_Gottlieb_von_Bellingshausen#First_Russian_Antarctic_expedition" title="Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen">a Russian expedition</a> discovered the continent of <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, Russia joined alliances with various European powers, and fought against <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">France</a>. The <a href="/wiki/French_invasion_of_Russia" title="French invasion of Russia">French invasion of Russia</a> at the height of Napoleon's power in 1812 reached Moscow, but eventually failed miserably as the obstinate resistance in combination with the bitterly cold <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_winter" title="Russian winter">Russian winter</a> led to a disastrous defeat of invaders, in which the pan-European <a href="/wiki/Grande_Arm%C3%A9e" title="Grande ArmÃ©e">Grande ArmÃ©e</a> faced utter destruction. Led by <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Kutuzov" title="Mikhail Kutuzov">Mikhail Kutuzov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Andreas_Barclay_de_Tolly" title="Michael Andreas Barclay de Tolly">Michael Andreas Barclay de Tolly</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Russian_Army" title="Imperial Russian Army">Imperial Russian Army</a> ousted Napoleon and drove throughout Europe in the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Sixth_Coalition" title="War of the Sixth Coalition">War of the Sixth Coalition</a>, ultimately entering Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[86]</a></sup> AlexanderÂ I controlled Russia's delegation at the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a>, which defined the map of post-Napoleonic Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="762" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg/220px-Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg/330px-Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg/440px-Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>'s retreat from Moscow</i> by <a href="/wiki/Albrecht_Adam" title="Albrecht Adam">Albrecht Adam</a> (1851).</div></div></div>
<p>The officers who pursued Napoleon into Western Europe brought ideas of liberalism back to Russia, and attempted to curtail the tsar's powers during the abortive <a href="/wiki/Decembrist_revolt" title="Decembrist revolt">Decembrist revolt</a> of 1825.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[88]</a></sup> At the end of the conservative reign of <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_I_of_Russia" title="Nicholas I of Russia">Nicholas I</a> (1825â1855), a zenith period of Russia's power and influence in Europe, was disrupted by defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">Crimean War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[89]</a></sup> Nicholas's successor <a href="/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia" title="Alexander II of Russia">AlexanderÂ II</a> (1855â1881) enacted significant changes throughout the country, including the <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_reform_of_1861" title="Emancipation reform of 1861">emancipation reform of 1861</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[90]</a></sup> These reforms spurred industrialisation, and modernised the Imperial Russian Army, which liberated much of the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> from Ottoman rule in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877â1878)">1877â1878 Russo-Turkish War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[91]</a></sup> During most of the 19th and early 20th century, Russia and <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">Britain</a> colluded over <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Afghanistan" title="Emirate of Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> and its neighboring territories in <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central</a> and South Asia; the rivalry between the two major European empires came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/Great_Game" title="Great Game">Great Game</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>The late 19th century saw the rise of various socialist movements in Russia. AlexanderÂ II was assassinated in 1881 by revolutionary terrorists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[93]</a></sup> The reign of his son <a href="/wiki/Alexander_III_of_Russia" title="Alexander III of Russia">AlexanderÂ III</a> (1881â1894) was less liberal but more peaceful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup> Under last Russian emperor, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nicholas_II" title="Nicholas II">NicholasÂ II</a> (1894â1917), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revolution_of_1905" title="Revolution of 1905">Revolution of 1905</a> was triggered by the failure of the humiliating <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">Russo-Japanese War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[95]</a></sup>  The uprising was put down, but the government was forced to concede major reforms (<a href="/wiki/Russian_Constitution_of_1906" title="Russian Constitution of 1906">Russian Constitution of 1906</a>), including granting <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedoms of speech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly" title="Freedom of assembly">assembly</a>, the legalisation of political parties, and the creation of an elected legislative body, the <a href="/wiki/State_Duma_(Russian_Empire)" title="State Duma (Russian Empire)">State Duma</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Revolution_and_civil_war">Revolution and civil war</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3281" data-file-width="3711" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg/220px-Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg/330px-Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg/440px-Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia" title="Nicholas II of Russia">Nicholas II of Russia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Romanov" title="House of Romanov">Romanovs</a> were <a href="/wiki/Execution_of_the_Romanov_family" title="Execution of the Romanov family">executed</a> by the Bolsheviks in 1918.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1914, <a href="/wiki/Russian_entry_into_World_War_I" title="Russian entry into World War I">Russia entered World WarÂ I</a> in response to <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>'s declaration of war on Russia's ally <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[97]</a></sup> and fought across multiple fronts while isolated from its <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a> allies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup> In 1916, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brusilov_Offensive" title="Brusilov Offensive">Brusilov Offensive</a> of the Imperial Russian Army almost completely destroyed the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Army" title="Austro-Hungarian Army">Austro-Hungarian Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[99]</a></sup> However, the already-existing public distrust of the regime was deepened by the rising costs of war, <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">high casualties</a>, and rumors of corruption and treason. All this formed the climate for the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> of 1917, carried out in two major acts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-revolution_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-revolution-104">[100]</a></sup> In early 1917, <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia" title="Nicholas II of Russia">Nicholas II</a> was <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">forced to abdicate</a>; he and his family were imprisoned and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shooting_of_the_Romanov_family" title="Shooting of the Romanov family">later executed</a> in <a href="/wiki/Yekaterinburg" title="Yekaterinburg">Yekaterinburg</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[101]</a></sup> The monarchy was replaced by a shaky coalition of political parties that declared itself the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Provisional Government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[102]</a></sup> The Provisional Government proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Republic" title="Russian Republic">Russian Republic</a> in September. On 19 January [<a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">O.S.</a> 6 January], 1918, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Constituent_Assembly" title="Russian Constituent Assembly">Russian Constituent Assembly</a> declared Russia a democratic federal republic (thus ratifying the Provisional Government's decision). The next day the Constituent Assembly was dissolved by the <a href="/wiki/All-Russian_Central_Executive_Committee" title="All-Russian Central Executive Committee">All-Russian Central Executive Committee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-revolution_104-1"><a href="#cite_note-revolution-104">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>An alternative socialist establishment co-existed, the <a href="/wiki/Petrograd_Soviet" title="Petrograd Soviet">Petrograd Soviet</a>, wielding power through the democratically elected councils of workers and peasants, called <i><a href="/wiki/Soviet_(council)" title="Soviet (council)">Soviets</a></i>. The rule of the new authorities only aggravated the crisis in the country instead of resolving it, and eventually, the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a>, led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bolshevik" title="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>, overthrew the Provisional Government and gave full governing power to the Soviets, leading to the creation of the world's first <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-revolution_104-2"><a href="#cite_note-revolution-104">[100]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> broke out between the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-communist" title="Anti-communist">anti-communist</a> <a href="/wiki/White_movement" title="White movement">White movement</a> and the new <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_council" title="Workers' council">Soviet</a> regime with its <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[103]</a></sup> In the aftermath of signing the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> that concluded hostilities with the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World WarÂ I</a>; Bolshevist Russia surrendered most of its western territories, which hosted 34% of its population, 54% of its industries, 32% of its agricultural land, and roughly 90% of its coal mines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3560" data-file-width="5315" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg/220px-After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg/330px-After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg/440px-After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:After_Lenin_Speech_1920.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a> during a 1920 speech in Moscow</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied powers</a> launched an unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Allied_intervention_in_the_Russian_Civil_War" title="Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War">military intervention</a> in support of anti-communist forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[105]</a></sup> In the meantime, both the Bolsheviks and White movement carried out campaigns of deportations and executions against each other, known respectively as the <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror" title="Red Terror">Red Terror</a> and <a href="/wiki/White_Terror_(Russia)" title="White Terror (Russia)">White Terror</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[106]</a></sup> By the end of the violent civil war, Russia's economy and infrastructure were heavily damaged, and as many as 10 million perished during the war, mostly civilians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[107]</a></sup> Millions became <a href="/wiki/White_%C3%A9migr%C3%A9" title="White Ã©migrÃ©">White Ã©migrÃ©s</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[108]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1921%E2%80%931922" title="Russian famine of 1921â1922">Russian famine of 1921â1922</a> claimed up to fiveÂ million victims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Soviet_Union">Soviet Union</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="History of the Soviet Union">History of the Soviet Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_(1936).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="376" data-file-width="592" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281936%29.svg/220px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281936%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281936%29.svg/330px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281936%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281936%29.svg/440px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281936%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_(1936).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Location of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian SFSR</a> (red) within the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> in 1936</div></div></div>
<p>On 30 December 1922, Lenin and his aides <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Creation_of_the_USSR" title="Treaty on the Creation of the USSR">formed</a> the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, by joining the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian SFSR</a> into a single state with the <a href="/wiki/Byelorussian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic">Byelorussian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transcaucasian_Socialist_Federative_Soviet_Republic" title="Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic">Transcaucasian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian</a> republics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[110]</a></sup> Eventually internal border changes and annexations during World War II created a union of <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Republics of the Soviet Union">15 republics</a>; the largest in size and population being the Russian SFSR, which dominated the union for its entire history politically, culturally, and economically.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[111]</a></sup> Following <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Vladimir_Lenin" title="Death and state funeral of Vladimir Lenin">Lenin's death</a> in 1924, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Troikas_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="List of Troikas in the Soviet Union">troika</a> was designated to take charge. Eventually <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">General Secretary of the Communist Party</a>, managed to suppress all opposition factions and consolidate power in his hands to become the country's dictator by the 1930s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a>, the main proponent of <a href="/wiki/World_revolution" title="World revolution">world revolution</a>, was exiled from the Soviet Union in 1929,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> and Stalin's idea of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialism_in_One_Country" title="Socialism in One Country">Socialism in One Country</a> became the official line.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-death_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-death-118">[114]</a></sup> The continued internal struggle in the Bolshevik party culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Purge</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Stalin's leadership, the government launched a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Command_economy" title="Command economy">command economy</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_USSR" title="Industrialization in the USSR">industrialisation of the largely rural country</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_USSR" title="Collectivization in the USSR">collectivisation</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_USSR" title="Agriculture in the USSR">its agriculture</a>. During this period of rapid economic and social change, millions of people were sent to <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">penal labor camps</a>, including many political convicts for their suspected or real opposition to Stalin's rule;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[116]</a></sup> and millions were <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">deported and exiled</a> to remote areas of the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[117]</a></sup> The transitional disorganisation of the country's agriculture, combined with the harsh state policies and a drought, led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%931933" title="Soviet famine of 1932â1933">Soviet famine of 1932â1933</a>; which killed up to 8.7 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[118]</a></sup> The Soviet Union, ultimately, made the costly transformation from a largely agrarian economy to a major industrial powerhouse within a short span of time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h4>
