<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_in_World_War_II" title="Soviet Union in World War II">Soviet Union in World War II</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3543" data-file-width="5332" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a>, the largest and bloodiest battle in the history of warfare, ended in 1943 with a decisive Soviet victory against the <a href="/wiki/German_Army_(1935%E2%80%931945)" title="German Army (1935â1945)">German army</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Soviet Union entered <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> on 17 September 1939 with its <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">invasion of Poland</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[120]</a></sup> in accordance with a secret protocol within the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="MolotovâRibbentrop Pact">MolotovâRibbentrop Pact</a> with <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[121]</a></sup> The Soviet Union later <a href="/wiki/Winter_War" title="Winter War">invaded Finland</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[122]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">occupied and annexed the Baltic states</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[123]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_Northern_Bukovina" title="Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina">parts of Romania</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 91â95">:â91â95â</span></sup> On 22 June 1941, Germany <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invaded the Soviet Union</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[125]</a></sup> opening the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a>, the largest theater of World WarÂ II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 7">:â7â</span></sup>
</p><p>Eventually, some 5 million <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> troops were captured by the Nazis;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 272">:â272â</span></sup> the latter deliberately <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war" title="German mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war">starved to death or otherwise killed</a> 3.3Â million Soviet <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_war" title="Prisoner of war">POWs</a>, and a vast number of civilians, as the "<a href="/wiki/Hunger_Plan" title="Hunger Plan">Hunger Plan</a>" sought to fulfill <a href="/wiki/Generalplan_Ost" title="Generalplan Ost">Generalplan Ost</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Snyder_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-Snyder-132">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 175â186">:â175â186â</span></sup> Although the <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> had considerable early success, their attack was halted in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moscow" title="Battle of Moscow">Battle of Moscow</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[129]</a></sup> Subsequently, the Germans were dealt major defeats first at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a> in the winter of 1942â1943,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[130]</a></sup> and then in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kursk" title="Battle of Kursk">Battle of Kursk</a> in the summer of 1943.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[131]</a></sup> Another German failure was the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad" title="Siege of Leningrad">Siege of Leningrad</a>, in which the city was fully blockaded on land between 1941 and 1944 by German and Finnish forces, and suffered starvation and more than a million deaths, but never surrendered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[132]</a></sup> Soviet forces steamrolled through Eastern and Central Europe in 1944â1945 and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin" title="Battle of Berlin">captured Berlin</a> in May 1945.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[133]</a></sup> In August 1945, the Red Army <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria" title="Soviet invasion of Manchuria">invaded Manchuria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War" title="SovietâJapanese War">ousted the Japanese</a> from Northeast Asia, contributing to the Allied victory over Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1941â1945 period of World WarÂ II is known in Russia as the <a href="/wiki/Great_Patriotic_War_(term)" title="Great Patriotic War (term)">Great Patriotic War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[135]</a></sup> The Soviet Union, along with the United States, the United Kingdom and China were considered the Big Four of Allied powers in World War II, and later became the <a href="/wiki/Four_Policemen" title="Four Policemen">Four Policemen</a>, which was the foundation of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 27">:â27â</span></sup> During the war, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="World War II casualties of the Soviet Union">Soviet civilian and military death were about 26â27 million</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[137]</a></sup> accounting for about half of all <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">World WarÂ II casualties</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 295">:â295â</span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Economy of the Soviet Union">Soviet economy</a> and infrastructure suffered massive devastation, which caused the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1946%E2%80%931947" title="Soviet famine of 1946â1947">Soviet famine of 1946â1947</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[139]</a></sup> However, at the expense of a large sacrifice, the Soviet Union emerged as a global superpower.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-superpower_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-superpower-144">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cold_War">Cold War</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yalta_Conference_(Churchill,_Roosevelt,_Stalin)_(B%26W).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2239" data-file-width="2720" decoding="async" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg/220px-Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg/330px-Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg/440px-Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yalta_Conference_(Churchill,_Roosevelt,_Stalin)_(B%26W).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Alliance_(World_War_II)" title="Grand Alliance (World War II)">Big Three</a>" at the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a> in February 1945, <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>After World War II, parts of Eastern and Central Europe, including <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a> and eastern parts of <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a> were occupied by <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Conference" title="Potsdam Conference">Potsdam Conference</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[141]</a></sup>  Dependent communist governments were installed in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> satellite states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[142]</a></sup> After becoming the world's second <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">nuclear power</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[143]</a></sup> the Soviet Union established the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> alliance,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[144]</a></sup> and entered into a struggle for global dominance, known as the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, with the rivaling United States and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[145]</a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Joseph_Stalin" title="Death and state funeral of Joseph Stalin">Stalin's death</a> in 1953 and a short period of <a href="/wiki/Collective_leadership" title="Collective leadership">collective rule</a>, the new leader <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> denounced <a href="/wiki/On_the_Cult_of_Personality_and_Its_Consequences" title="On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences">Stalin</a> and launched the policy of <a href="/wiki/De-Stalinization" title="De-Stalinization">de-Stalinization</a>, releasing many political prisoners from the <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">Gulag</a> labor camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[146]</a></sup> The general easement of repressive policies became known later as the <a href="/wiki/Khrushchev_Thaw" title="Khrushchev Thaw">Khrushchev Thaw</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[147]</a></sup> At the same time, Cold War tensions reached its peak when the two rivals clashed over the deployment of the United States <a href="/wiki/PGM-19_Jupiter" title="PGM-19 Jupiter">Jupiter missiles</a> in Turkey and Soviet <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">missiles in Cuba</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1957, the Soviet Union launched the world's first artificial <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">SputnikÂ 1</a></i>, thus starting the <a href="/wiki/Space_Age" title="Space Age">Space Age</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[149]</a></sup> Russian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cosmonaut" title="Cosmonaut">cosmonaut</a> <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a> became the first human to orbit the Earth, aboard the <i><a href="/wiki/Vostok_1" title="Vostok 1">VostokÂ 1</a></i> manned spacecraft on <a href="/wiki/Cosmonautics_Day" title="Cosmonautics Day">12 April 1961</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[150]</a></sup> Following the ousting of Khrushchev in 1964, another period of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collectivity_of_leadership" title="Collectivity of leadership">collective rule</a> ensued, until <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev" title="Leonid Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a> became the leader. The era of the 1970s and the early 1980s was later designated as the <a href="/wiki/Era_of_Stagnation" title="Era of Stagnation">Era of Stagnation</a>. The 1965 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kosygin_reform" title="Kosygin reform">Kosygin reform</a> aimed for partial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decentralisation" title="Decentralisation">decentralisation</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_economy" title="Soviet economy">Soviet economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[151]</a></sup> In 1979, after a <a href="/wiki/Saur_Revolution" title="Saur Revolution">communist-led revolution</a> in Afghanistan, Soviet forces invaded the country, ultimately starting the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">SovietâAfghan War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[152]</a></sup> In May 1988, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_withdrawal_from_Afghanistan" title="Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan">Soviets started to withdraw from Afghanistan</a>, due to international opposition, persistent anti-Soviet guerrilla warfare, and a lack of support by Soviet citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[153]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2655" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg/220px-President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg/330px-President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg/440px-President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Reagan_meeting_with_Soviet_General_Secretary_Gorbachev_at_Hofdi_House_during_the_Reykjavik_Summit_Iceland.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> in one-to-one discussions with <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Reykjav%C3%ADk_Summit" title="ReykjavÃ­k Summit">ReykjavÃ­k Summit</a>, 1986.</div></div></div>
<p>From 1985 onwards, the last Soviet leader <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, who sought to enact liberal reforms in the Soviet system, introduced the policies of <i><a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">glasnost</a></i> (openness) and <i><a href="/wiki/Perestroika" title="Perestroika">perestroika</a></i> (restructuring) in an attempt to end the <a href="/wiki/Era_of_Stagnation" title="Era of Stagnation">period of economic stagnation</a> and to <a href="/wiki/Demokratizatsiya_(Soviet_Union)" title="Demokratizatsiya (Soviet Union)">democratise the government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[154]</a></sup> This, however, led to the rise of strong nationalist and separatist movements across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[155]</a></sup> Prior to 1991, the Soviet economy was the world's second-largest, but during its final years, it went into a crisis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 1991, economic and political turmoil began to boil over as the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic states</a> chose to secede from the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[157]</a></sup> On 17 March, a <a href="/wiki/1991_Soviet_Union_referendum" title="1991 Soviet Union referendum">referendum</a> was held, in which the vast majority of participating citizens voted in favour of changing the Soviet Union into a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Union_of_Sovereign_States" title="Union of Sovereign States">renewed federation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[158]</a></sup> In June 1991, <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a> became the first directly elected <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">president</a> in Russian history when he was <a href="/wiki/1991_Russian_presidential_election" title="1991 Russian presidential election">elected</a> president of the Russian SFSR.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[159]</a></sup> In August 1991, <a href="/wiki/1991_Soviet_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="1991 Soviet coup d'Ã©tat attempt">a coup d'Ã©tat attempt</a> by members of Gorbachev's government, directed against Gorbachev and aimed at preserving the Soviet Union, instead led to the end of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[160]</a></sup> On 25 December 1991, following the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>, along with contemporary Russia, fourteen other <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_states" title="Post-Soviet states">post-Soviet states</a> emerged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Post-Soviet_Russia_.281991.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Soviet_Russia_(1991âpresent)">Post-Soviet Russia (1991âpresent)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Russia_(1991%E2%80%93present)" title="History of Russia (1991âpresent)">History of Russia (1991âpresent)</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Boris_Yeltsin" title="Presidency of Boris Yeltsin">Presidency of Boris Yeltsin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia_under_Vladimir_Putin" title="Russia under Vladimir Putin">Russia under Vladimir Putin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Presidency of Dmitry Medvedev">Presidency of Dmitry Medvedev</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath,_7_May_2000.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath%2C_7_May_2000.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath%2C_7_May_2000.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath%2C_7_May_2000.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath%2C_7_May_2000.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath%2C_7_May_2000.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath%2C_7_May_2000.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_taking_the_Presidential_Oath,_7_May_2000.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> takes the oath of office as president on his <a href="/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Vladimir_Putin" title="First inauguration of Vladimir Putin">first inauguration</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a> looking over, 2000.</div></div></div>
<p>The economic and political collapse of the Soviet Union led Russia into a deep and prolonged depression. During and after the disintegration of the Soviet Union, wide-ranging reforms including <a href="/wiki/Privatization_in_Russia" title="Privatization in Russia">privatisation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Free_trade" title="Free trade">market and trade liberalisation</a> were undertaken, including radical changes along the lines of "<a href="/wiki/Shock_therapy_(economics)" title="Shock therapy (economics)">shock therapy</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup> The privatisation largely shifted control of enterprises from state agencies to individuals with inside connections in the government, which led to the rise of the infamous <a href="/wiki/Russian_oligarchs" title="Russian oligarchs">Russian oligarchs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup> Many of the newly rich moved billions in cash and assets outside of the country in an enormous <a href="/wiki/Capital_flight" title="Capital flight">capital flight</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[164]</a></sup> The depression of the economy led to the collapse of social servicesâthe <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> plummeted while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_rate" title="Death rate">death rate</a> skyrocketed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[166]</a></sup> and millions plunged into poverty;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[167]</a></sup> while extreme corruption,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[168]</a></sup> as well as criminal gangs and organised crime rose significantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late 1993, tensions between Yeltsin and the Russian parliament culminated in <a href="/wiki/1993_Russian_constitutional_crisis" title="1993 Russian constitutional crisis">a constitutional crisis</a> which ended violently through military force. During the crisis, Yeltsin was backed by Western governments, and over 100 people were killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup> In December, a <a href="/wiki/1993_Russian_constitutional_referendum" title="1993 Russian constitutional referendum">referendum</a> was held and approved, which introduced a new constitution, giving the president enormous powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[171]</a></sup> The 1990s were plagued by armed conflicts in the <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a>, both local ethnic skirmishes and separatist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamist" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> insurrections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[172]</a></sup> From the time <a href="/wiki/Chechnya" title="Chechnya">Chechen</a> separatists declared independence in the early 1990s, an <a href="/wiki/First_Chechen_War" title="First Chechen War">intermittent guerrilla war</a> was fought between the rebel groups and Russian forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[173]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Terrorism_in_Russia" title="Terrorism in Russia">Terrorist attacks against civilians</a> were carried out by Chechen separatists, claiming the lives of thousands of Russian civilians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[e]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Russia assumed responsibility for settling the latter's external debts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[175]</a></sup> In 1992, most consumer price controls were eliminated, causing extreme inflation and significantly devaluing the ruble.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[176]</a></sup> High budget deficits coupled with increasing capital flight and inability to pay back debts, caused the <a href="/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis" title="1998 Russian financial crisis">1998 Russian financial crisis</a>, which resulted in a further GDP decline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov,_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2722" data-file-width="4091" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg/220px-Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg/330px-Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg/440px-Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov,_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vladimir Putin (third, left), <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Aksyonov" title="Sergey Aksyonov">Sergey Aksyonov</a> (first, left), <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Konstantinov_(politician)" title="Vladimir Konstantinov (politician)">Vladimir Konstantinov</a> (second, left) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aleksei_Chalyi" title="Aleksei Chalyi">Aleksei Chalyi</a> (right) sign the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_on_Accession_of_the_Republic_of_Crimea_to_Russia" title="Treaty on Accession of the Republic of Crimea to Russia">Treaty on Accession of the Republic of Crimea to Russia</a> in 2014</div></div></div>
<p>In 1999, president Yeltsin unexpectedly resigned, handing the post to the recently appointed prime minister and his chosen successor, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[178]</a></sup> Putin then won the <a href="/wiki/2000_Russian_presidential_election" title="2000 Russian presidential election">2000 presidential election</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[179]</a></sup> and defeated the Chechen insurgency in the <a href="/wiki/Second_Chechen_War" title="Second Chechen War">Second Chechen War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[180]</a></sup> Putin won a <a href="/wiki/2004_Russian_presidential_election" title="2004 Russian presidential election">second presidential term</a> in 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[181]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Price_of_petroleum" title="Price of petroleum">High oil prices</a> and a rise in foreign investment saw the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_economy" title="Russian economy">Russian economy</a> and living standards improve significantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Putineconomy_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-Putineconomy-187">[182]</a></sup> Putin's rule increased stability, while transforming Russia into an <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism#Examples" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[183]</a></sup> In 2008, Putin took the post of prime minister, while <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a> was <a href="/wiki/2008_Russian_presidential_election" title="2008 Russian presidential election">elected president</a> for one term, to hold onto power despite legal <a href="/wiki/Term_limit" title="Term limit">term limits</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[184]</a></sup> this period has been described as a "<a href="/wiki/Medvedev%E2%80%93Putin_tandemocracy" title="MedvedevâPutin tandemocracy">tandemocracy</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a <a href="/wiki/2008_Russo-Georgian_diplomatic_crisis" title="2008 Russo-Georgian diplomatic crisis">diplomatic crisis</a> with neighboring <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Georgian_War" title="Russo-Georgian War">Russo-Georgian War</a> took place during 1â12 August 2008, resulting in Russia imposing two unrecognised states in the <a href="/wiki/Occupied_territories_of_Georgia" title="Occupied territories of Georgia">occupied territories of Georgia</a>. It was the first <a href="/wiki/List_of_conflicts_in_Europe" title="List of conflicts in Europe">European war</a> of the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[186]</a></sup> In 2014, following <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">a revolution</a> in Ukraine, Russia <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">invaded and annexed</a> the neighboring country's Crimean peninsula,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[187]</a></sup> and contributed to the outbreak of <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbas_(2014%E2%80%932022)" title="War in Donbas (2014â2022)">war in eastern Ukraine</a> with direct intervention by Russian troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[188]</a></sup> Russia steeply escalated the ongoing <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russo-Ukrainian War</a> by launching a <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">full-scale invasion of Ukraine</a> on 24 February 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[189]</a></sup> The invasion marked the largest <a href="/wiki/Conventional_warfare" title="Conventional warfare">conventional war</a> in Europe since World WarÂ II,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[190]</a></sup> and was met with <a href="/wiki/Government_and_intergovernmental_reactions_to_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Government and intergovernmental reactions to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">widespread international condemnation</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[191]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="International sanctions during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">expanded sanctions</a> against Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sanction1_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-sanction1-197">[192]</a></sup> As a result, Russia was expelled from the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> in March,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CoE_Expulsion_RU_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-CoE_Expulsion_RU-198">[193]</a></sup> and suspended from the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">United Nations Human Rights Council</a> in April.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[194]</a></sup> In September 2022, Putin proclaimed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Southern_and_Eastern_Ukraine" title="Annexation of Southern and Eastern Ukraine">annexation of 15% of Ukraine's landmass</a> in its <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_Oblast" title="Donetsk Oblast">Donetsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kherson_Oblast" title="Kherson Oblast">Kherson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luhansk_Oblast" title="Luhansk Oblast">Luhansk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Oblast" title="Zaporizhzhia Oblast">Zaporizhzhia</a> regions, the largest seizure attempted in Europe since World WarÂ II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Russia" title="Geography of Russia">Geography of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1896" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png/290px-Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png/435px-Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png/580px-Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Russian_Federation_Relief_Map.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Topographic_map" title="Topographic map">Topographic map</a> of Russia</div></div></div>
<p>Russia's vast landmass stretches over the easternmost part of Europe and the northernmost part of Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natgeo_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo-201">[196]</a></sup> It spans the northernmost edge of <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>; and has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">fourth-longest coastline</a>, of over 37,653Â km (23,396Â mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[f]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[198]</a></sup> Russia lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/41st_parallel_north" title="41st parallel north">41Â°</a> and <a href="/wiki/82nd_parallel_north" title="82nd parallel north">82Â° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/19th_meridian_east" title="19th meridian east">19Â° E</a> and <a href="/wiki/169th_meridian_west" title="169th meridian west">169Â° W</a>, extending some 9,000Â km (5,600Â mi) east to west, and 2,500 to 4,000Â km (1,600 to 2,500Â mi) north to south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[199]</a></sup> Russia, by landmass, is larger than three continents,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[g]</a></sup> and has the same surface area as <a href="/wiki/Pluto" title="Pluto">Pluto</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia has nine major mountain ranges, and they are found along the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Russia" title="Southern Russia">southernmost regions</a>, which share a significant portion of the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains" title="Caucasus Mountains">Caucasus Mountains</a> (containing <a href="/wiki/Mount_Elbrus" title="Mount Elbrus">Mount Elbrus</a>, which at 5,642Â m (18,510Â ft) is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_elevation_extremes_by_region" title="List of elevation extremes by region">highest peak</a> in Russia and Europe);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Altai_Mountains" title="Altai Mountains">Altai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sayan_Mountains" title="Sayan Mountains">Sayan Mountains</a> in <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>; and in the <a href="/wiki/East_Siberian_Mountains" title="East Siberian Mountains">East Siberian Mountains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kamchatka_Peninsula" title="Kamchatka Peninsula">Kamchatka Peninsula</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Russian Far East</a> (containing <a href="/wiki/Klyuchevskaya_Sopka" title="Klyuchevskaya Sopka">Klyuchevskaya Sopka</a>, which at 4,750Â m (15,584Â ft) is the highest <a href="/wiki/Active_volcano" title="Active volcano">active volcano</a> in Eurasia).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[201]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Topo_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-Topo-209">[202]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>, running north to south through the country's west, are rich in mineral resources, and form the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boundary_between_Europe_and_Asia" title="Boundary between Europe and Asia">traditional boundary between Europe and Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-urals_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-urals-210">[203]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Extreme_points_of_Europe#Elevation" title="Extreme points of Europe">lowest point in Russia and Europe</a>, is situated at the head of the Caspian Sea, where the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Depression" title="Caspian Depression">Caspian Depression</a> reaches some 29 metres (95.1Â ft) below sea level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia, as one of the world's only three countries <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_bordering_on_two_or_more_oceans" title="List of countries bordering on two or more oceans">bordering three oceans</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natgeo_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo-201">[196]</a></sup> has links with a great number of seas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[h]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geo_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-Geo-213">[205]</a></sup> Its major islands and archipelagos include <a href="/wiki/Novaya_Zemlya" title="Novaya Zemlya">Novaya Zemlya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franz_Josef_Land" title="Franz Josef Land">Franz Josef Land</a>, <a href="/wiki/Severnaya_Zemlya" title="Severnaya Zemlya">Severnaya Zemlya</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_Siberian_Islands" title="New Siberian Islands">New Siberian Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wrangel_Island" title="Wrangel Island">Wrangel Island</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kuril Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arctic_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-Arctic-214">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Diomede_Islands" title="Diomede Islands">Diomede Islands</a>, administered by Russia and the United States, are just 3.8Â km (2.4Â mi) apart;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[208]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kunashir_Island" title="Kunashir Island">Kunashir Island</a> of the Kuril Islands is merely 20Â km (12.4Â mi) from <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a>, Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chapple-2019_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-chapple-2019-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia, home of over 100,000 rivers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natgeo_201-2"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo-201">[196]</a></sup> has one of the world's largest surface water resources, with its lakes containing approximately one-quarter of the world's liquid <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Topo_209-1"><a href="#cite_note-Topo-209">[202]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lake_Baikal" title="Lake Baikal">Lake Baikal</a>, the largest and most prominent among Russia's fresh water bodies, is the world's deepest, purest, oldest and most capacious fresh water lake, containing over one-fifth of the world's fresh surface water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[209]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lake_Ladoga" title="Lake Ladoga">Ladoga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Onega" title="Lake Onega">Onega</a> in <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Russia" title="Northwest Russia">northwestern Russia</a> are two of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_lakes_of_Europe" title="List of largest lakes of Europe">largest lakes in Europe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natgeo_201-3"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo-201">[196]</a></sup> Russia is second only to Brazil by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_renewable_water_resources" title="List of countries by total renewable water resources">total renewable water resources</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[210]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Volga" title="Volga">Volga</a> in western Russia, widely regarded as Russia's national river, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Europe#Rivers_of_Europe_by_length" title="List of rivers of Europe">longest river</a> in Europe; and forms the <a href="/wiki/Volga_Delta" title="Volga Delta">Volga Delta</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/River_delta" title="River delta">river delta</a> in the continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[211]</a></sup> The Siberian rivers of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ob_River" title="Ob River">Ob</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yenisey" title="Yenisey">Yenisey</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lena_River" title="Lena River">Lena</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amur_River" title="Amur River">Amur</a> are among the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_length" title="List of rivers by length">longest rivers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Russia" title="Climate of Russia">Climate of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="792" data-file-width="990" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/300px-Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/450px-Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/600px-Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen climate classification</a> of Russia.</div></div></div>
<p>The size of Russia and the remoteness of many of its areas from the sea result in the dominance of the <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> throughout most of the country, except for the tundra and the extreme southwest. Mountain ranges in the south and east obstruct the flow of warm air masses from the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian</a> and Pacific oceans, while the <a href="/wiki/European_Plain" title="European Plain">European Plain</a> spanning its west and north opens it to influence from the Atlantic and Arctic oceans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-221">[213]</a></sup> Most of northwest Russia and Siberia have a <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">subarctic climate</a>, with extremely severe winters in the inner regions of northeast Siberia (mostly <a href="/wiki/Sakha" title="Sakha">Sakha</a>, where the Northern <a href="/wiki/Pole_of_Cold" title="Pole of Cold">Pole of Cold</a> is located with the record low temperature of â71.2Â Â°C or â96.2Â Â°F),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arctic_214-1"><a href="#cite_note-Arctic-214">[206]</a></sup> and more moderate winters elsewhere. Russia's vast coastline along the Arctic Ocean and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Arctic_islands" title="Russian Arctic islands">Russian Arctic islands</a> have a <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">polar climate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_221-1"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-221">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>The coastal part of <a href="/wiki/Krasnodar_Krai" title="Krasnodar Krai">Krasnodar Krai</a> on the Black Sea, most notably <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, and some coastal and interior strips of the <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a> possess a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> with mild and wet winters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_221-2"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-221">[213]</a></sup>  In many regions of East Siberia and the Russian Far East, winter is dry compared to summer; while other parts of the country experience more even precipitation across seasons. Winter precipitation in most parts of the country usually falls as snow. The westernmost parts of Kaliningrad Oblast and some parts in the south of Krasnodar Krai and the North Caucasus have an <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_221-3"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-221">[213]</a></sup> The region along the Lower Volga and Caspian Sea coast, as well as some southernmost slivers of Siberia, possess a <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid climate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout much of the territory, there are only two distinct seasons, winter and summer; as spring and autumn are usually brief periods of change between extremely low and extremely high temperatures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_221-4"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-221">[213]</a></sup> The coldest month is January (February on the coastline); the warmest is usually July. Great ranges of temperature are typical. In winter, temperatures get colder both from south to north and from west to east. Summers can be quite hot, even in Siberia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[215]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Russia" title="Climate change in Russia">Climate change in Russia</a> is causing more frequent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wildfires_in_Russia" title="Wildfires in Russia">wildfires</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[216]</a></sup> and thawing the country's large expanse of <a href="/wiki/Permafrost" title="Permafrost">permafrost</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Russia" title="Wildlife of Russia">Wildlife of Russia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_ecoregions_in_Russia" title="List of ecoregions in Russia">List of ecoregions in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1037" data-file-width="1549" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/330px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/440px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Yugyd_Va_National_Park" title="Yugyd Va National Park">Yugyd Va National Park</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Komi_Republic" title="Komi Republic">Komi Republic</a> is the largest <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national park</a> in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-urals_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-urals-210">[203]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Russia, owing to its gigantic size, has diverse ecosystems, including <a href="/wiki/Polar_desert" title="Polar desert">polar deserts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">tundra</a>, forest tundra, <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">taiga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Temperate_broadleaf_and_mixed_forests" title="Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests">mixed and broadleaf forest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Forest_steppe" title="Forest steppe">forest steppe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a>, semi-desert, and <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">subtropics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-climate-226">[218]</a></sup> About half of Russia's territory is forested,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-2"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> and it has the world's largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forest_reserves" title="Forest reserves">forest reserves</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-biodiversity_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-biodiversity-227">[219]</a></sup> which sequester some of the world's highest amounts of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russian biodiversity includes 12,500 species of <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">vascular plants</a>, 2,200 species of <a href="/wiki/Bryophyte" title="Bryophyte">bryophytes</a>, about 3,000 species of <a href="/wiki/Lichen" title="Lichen">lichens</a>, 7,000â9,000 species of <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a>, and 20,000â25,000 species of fungi. Russian <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a> is composed of <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Russia" title="List of mammals of Russia">320 species</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mammals" title="Mammals">mammals</a>, over <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Russia" title="List of birds of Russia">732 species</a> of birds, 75 species of reptiles, about 30 species of <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibians</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_freshwater_fish_of_Russia" title="List of freshwater fish of Russia">343 species</a> of <a href="/wiki/Freshwater_fish" title="Freshwater fish">freshwater fish</a> (high <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemism</a>), approximately 1,500 species of <a href="/wiki/Saltwater_fish" title="Saltwater fish">saltwater fishes</a>, 9 species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyclostomata" title="Cyclostomata">cyclostomata</a>, and approximately 100â150,000 <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">invertebrates</a> (high endemism).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_226-1"><a href="#cite_note-climate-226">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[221]</a></sup> Approximately 1,100 rare and endangered plant and animal species are included in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Data_Book_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Red Data Book of the Russian Federation">Russian Red Data Book</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_226-2"><a href="#cite_note-climate-226">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's entirely natural ecosystems are conserved in nearly 15,000 specially protected natural territories of various statuses, occupying more than 10% of the country's total area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_226-3"><a href="#cite_note-climate-226">[218]</a></sup> They include 45 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserve" title="Biosphere reserve">biosphere reserves</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[222]</a></sup> 64 <a href="/wiki/National_parks_of_Russia" title="National parks of Russia">national parks</a>, and 101 <a href="/wiki/Zapovednik" title="Zapovednik">nature reserves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[223]</a></sup> Russia still has many ecosystems which are still untouched by man; mainly in the northern taiga areas, and the subarctic tundra of Siberia.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Russia had a <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 9.02 in 2019, ranking 10th out of 172 countries; and the first ranked major nation globally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Russia" title="Politics of Russia">Politics of Russia</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:134px;max-width:134px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:203px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_(2018-03-01)_03_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2293" data-file-width="1486" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Vladimir_Putin_%282018-03-01%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/132px-Vladimir_Putin_%282018-03-01%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Vladimir_Putin_%282018-03-01%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/198px-Vladimir_Putin_%282018-03-01%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Vladimir_Putin_%282018-03-01%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/264px-Vladimir_Putin_%282018-03-01%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="132"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a><br/><small><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="President of the Russian Federation">President</a></small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:154px;max-width:154px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:203px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mikhail_Mishustin_(2020-07-09).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2524" data-file-width="1892" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Mikhail_Mishustin_%282020-07-09%29.jpg/152px-Mikhail_Mishustin_%282020-07-09%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Mikhail_Mishustin_%282020-07-09%29.jpg/228px-Mikhail_Mishustin_%282020-07-09%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Mikhail_Mishustin_%282020-07-09%29.jpg/304px-Mikhail_Mishustin_%282020-07-09%29.jpg 2x" width="152"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Mishustin" title="Mikhail Mishustin">Mikhail Mishustin</a><br/><small><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Prime Minister of the Russian Federation">Prime Minister</a></small></div></div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="744" data-file-width="1052" decoding="async" height="219" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg/310px-Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg/465px-Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg/620px-Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A chart of the Russian political system</div></div></div>
<p>Russia, by constitution, is an <a href="/wiki/Asymmetric_federalism" title="Asymmetric federalism">asymmetric federal</a> republic,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[225]</a></sup> with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a>, wherein the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">president</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-234">[226]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Russia" title="Prime Minister of Russia">prime minister</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-3"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> It is structured as a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>, with the federal government composed of three branches:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeRouenHeo2005_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouenHeo2005-235">[227]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Legislative: The <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Federal_Assembly_(Russia)" title="Federal Assembly (Russia)">Federal Assembly of Russia</a>, made up of the 450-member <a href="/wiki/State_Duma" title="State Duma">State Duma</a> and the 170-member <a href="/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia)" title="Federation Council (Russia)">Federation Council</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeRouenHeo2005_235-1"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouenHeo2005-235">[227]</a></sup> adopts <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">declares war</a>, approves treaties, has the <a href="/wiki/Power_of_the_purse" title="Power of the purse">power of the purse</a> and the power of <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeachment</a> of the president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[228]</a></sup></li>
<li>Executive: The president is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander-in-Chief_of_the_Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Supreme Commander-in-Chief of the Russian Armed Forces">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Armed Forces</a>, and appoints the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Russia" title="Government of Russia">Government of Russia</a> (Cabinet) and other officers, who administer and enforce federal laws and policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-234">[226]</a></sup> The president may issue <a href="/wiki/Decree_of_the_President_of_Russia" title="Decree of the President of Russia">decrees of unlimited scope</a>, so long as they do not contradict the constitution or federal law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[229]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Russia" title="Judiciary of Russia">Judiciary</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Russia" title="Constitutional Court of Russia">Constitutional Court</a>, <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Russia" title="Supreme Court of Russia">Supreme Court</a> and lower federal courts, whose judges are appointed by the Federation Council on the recommendation of the president,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeRouenHeo2005_235-2"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouenHeo2005-235">[227]</a></sup> interpret laws and can overturn laws they deem <a href="/wiki/Constitutionality" title="Constitutionality">unconstitutional</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[230]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>The president is elected by popular vote for a six-year term and may be elected no more than twice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[i]</a></sup> Ministries of the government are composed of the premier and his deputies, ministers, and selected other individuals; all are appointed by the president on the recommendation of the prime minister (whereas the appointment of the latter requires the consent of the State Duma). <a href="/wiki/United_Russia" title="United Russia">United Russia</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Dominant-party_system#Eurasia" title="Dominant-party system">dominant</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Russia" title="List of political parties in Russia">political party in Russia</a>, and has been described as "<a href="/wiki/Big_tent" title="Big tent">big tent</a>" and the "<a href="/wiki/Party_of_power" title="Party of power">party of power</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[234]</a></sup> Under the <a href="/wiki/Russia_under_Vladimir_Putin" title="Russia under Vladimir Putin">administrations of Vladimir Putin</a>, Russia has experienced <a href="/wiki/Democratic_backsliding" title="Democratic backsliding">democratic backsliding</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[235]</a></sup> and has become an <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian state</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-authoritarianness_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-authoritarianness-9">[7]</a></sup> under a dictatorship,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[238]</a></sup> with Putin's policies being referred to as <a href="/wiki/Putinism" title="Putinism">Putinism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[239]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_divisions">Political divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_divisions_of_Russia" title="Political divisions of Russia">Political divisions of Russia</a></div>
<p>According to the constitution, the Russian Federation is composed of 89 <a href="/wiki/Federal_subjects_of_Russia" title="Federal subjects of Russia">federal subjects</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[j]</a></sup> In 1993, when the new constitution was adopted, there were 89 federal subjects listed, but <a href="/wiki/Federal_subjects_of_Russia#Mergers,_splits_and_internal_territorial_changes" title="Federal subjects of Russia">some were later merged</a>. The federal subjects have equal representationâtwo delegates eachâin the <a href="/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia)" title="Federation Council (Russia)">Federation Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Upper_house" title="Upper house">upper house</a> of the Federal Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[240]</a></sup> They do, however, differ in the degree of <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_administrative_division" title="Autonomous administrative division">autonomy</a> they enjoy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[241]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Federal_districts_of_Russia" title="Federal districts of Russia">federal districts of Russia</a> were established by Putin in 2000 to facilitate central government control of the federal subjects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[242]</a></sup> Originally seven, currently there are eight federal districts, each headed by an envoy appointed by the president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[243]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_(2014),_disputed_Crimea.svg"><img alt="Map of federal subjects of Russia (2014), disputed Crimea.svg" data-file-height="282" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29%2C_disputed_Crimea.svg/600px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29%2C_disputed_Crimea.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29%2C_disputed_Crimea.svg/900px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29%2C_disputed_Crimea.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29%2C_disputed_Crimea.svg/1200px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29%2C_disputed_Crimea.svg.png 2x" width="600"/></a></div></div>
<table class="wikitable sortable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Federal subjects
</th>
<th>Governance
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFEC77; color:black;">Â </span>Â 46Â <a href="/wiki/Oblasts_of_Russia" title="Oblasts of Russia">oblasts</a></div>
</td>
<td>The most common type of federal subject with a governor and locally elected legislature. Commonly named after their administrative centres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[244]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00C160; color:black;">Â </span>Â 22Â <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_Russia" title="Republics of Russia">republics</a></div>
</td>
<td>Each is nominally autonomousâhome to a specific <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia" title="Ethnic groups in Russia">ethnic minority</a>, and has its own constitution, language, and legislature, but is represented by the federal government in international affairs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[245]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF9400; color:black;">Â </span>Â 9Â <a href="/wiki/Krais_of_Russia" title="Krais of Russia">krais</a></div>
</td>
<td>For all intents and purposes, krais are legally identical to oblasts. The title "krai" ("frontier" or "territory") is historic, related to geographic (frontier) position in a certain period of history. The current krais are not related to frontiers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[246]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#006989; color:white;">Â </span>Â 4Â <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_okrugs_of_Russia" title="Autonomous okrugs of Russia">autonomous okrugs</a></div>
</td>
<td>Occasionally referred to as "autonomous district", "autonomous area", and "autonomous region", each with a substantial or predominant ethnic minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[247]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF0037; color:black;">Â </span>Â 3Â <a href="/wiki/Federal_cities_of_Russia" title="Federal cities of Russia">federal cities</a></div>
</td>
<td>Major cities that function as separate regions (Moscow, Saint Petersburg, and <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[248]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#C300FF; color:black;">Â </span>Â 1Â autonomous oblast</div>
</td>
<td>The only autonomous oblast is the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Autonomous_Oblast" title="Jewish Autonomous Oblast">Jewish Autonomous Oblast</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[249]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Russia" title="Foreign relations of Russia">Foreign relations of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2337" data-file-width="3506" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg/220px-2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg/330px-2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg/440px-2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Putin with G20 counterparts in <a href="/wiki/Osaka" title="Osaka">Osaka</a>, 2019.</div></div></div>
<p>Russia had the world's fifth-largest diplomatic network in 2019. It maintains diplomatic relations with 190 <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">United Nations member states</a>, four <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">partially-recognised states</a>, and three <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations#Observers_and_non-members" title="Member states of the United Nations">United Nations observer states</a>; along with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_embassies" title="Russian embassies">144 embassies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[250]</a></sup> Russia is one of the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">five permanent members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>. It has historically been a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[251]</a></sup> and a former <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">superpower</a> as the leading constituent of the former Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-superpower_144-1"><a href="#cite_note-superpower-144">[140]</a></sup> Russia is a member of the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>. Russia also takes a leading role in organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">CIS</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[252]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Union" title="Eurasian Economic Union">EAEU</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[253]</a></sup> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collective_Security_Treaty_Organisation" title="Collective Security Treaty Organisation">CSTO</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[254]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[255]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[256]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia maintains close relations <a href="/wiki/Belarus%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="BelarusâRussia relations">with neighbouring Belarus</a>, which is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Union_State" title="Union State">Union State</a>, a supranational confederation of the two states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[257]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a> has been a <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Serbia_relations" title="RussiaâSerbia relations">historically close ally</a> of Russia, as both countries share a strong mutual cultural, ethnic, and religious affinity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[258]</a></sup> India is the largest customer of Russian military equipment, and the two countries share a strong <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="IndiaâRussia relations">strategic and diplomatic relationship</a> since the Soviet era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[259]</a></sup> Russia wields enormous influence across the <a href="/wiki/Geopolitics" title="Geopolitics">geopolitically</a> important <a href="/wiki/South_Caucasus" title="South Caucasus">South Caucasus</a> and Central Asia; and the two regions have been described as Russia's "backyard".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 21st century, relations between Russia and China have significantly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sino-Russian_relations" title="Sino-Russian relations">strengthened bilaterally and economically</a>;
