due to shared political interests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[262]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> and Russia share a complex <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="RussiaâTurkey relations">strategic, energy, and defense relationship</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[263]</a></sup> Russia maintains <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="IranâRussia relations">cordial relations</a> with Iran, as it is a strategic and economic ally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[264]</a></sup> Russia has also increasingly pushed to expand its influence across the <a href="/wiki/Arctic" title="Arctic">Arctic</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[265]</a></sup> Asia-Pacific,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[266]</a></sup> Africa,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[267]</a></sup> the Middle East,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[268]</a></sup> and Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[269]</a></sup> In contrast, Russia's relations with <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations" title="RussiaâUkraine relations">neighboring Ukraine</a> and the Western worldâespecially the <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="RussiaâUnited States relations">United States</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="RussiaâEuropean Union relations">European Union</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="RussiaâNATO relations">NATO</a>âhave collapsed; following the start of the Russo-Ukrainian War in 2014 and the consequent escalation in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[271]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Russian Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sukhoi_Design_Bureau,_054,_Sukhoi_Su-57_(49581303977).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_Su-57_%2849581303977%29.jpg/220px-Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_Su-57_%2849581303977%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_Su-57_%2849581303977%29.jpg/330px-Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_Su-57_%2849581303977%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_Su-57_%2849581303977%29.jpg/440px-Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_Su-57_%2849581303977%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sukhoi_Design_Bureau,_054,_Sukhoi_Su-57_(49581303977).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-57" title="Sukhoi Su-57">Sukhoi Su-57</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Fifth-generation_fighter" title="Fifth-generation fighter">fifth-generation fighter</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Air_Force" title="Russian Air Force">Russian Air Force</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sukhoi_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sukhoi-282">[272]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Russian Armed Forces</a> are divided into the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Ground_Forces" title="Russian Ground Forces">Ground Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Navy" title="Russian Navy">Navy</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Aerospace_Force" title="Russian Aerospace Force">Aerospace Forces</a>âand there are also two independent arms of service: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Strategic_Missile_Troops" title="Strategic Missile Troops">Strategic Missile Troops</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Airborne_Troops" title="Russian Airborne Troops">Airborne Troops</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-4"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the military have around a million active-duty personnel, which is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">fifth-largest</a>, and about 2â20 million <a href="/wiki/Military_reserve_force" title="Military reserve force">reserve personnel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[274]</a></sup> It is mandatory for all male citizens aged 18â27 to be <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">drafted</a> for a year of service in the Armed Forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-5"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is among the five <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons">recognised</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear-weapons states</a>, with the world's <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">largest stockpile of nuclear weapons</a>; over half of the world's nuclear weapons are owned by Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[275]</a></sup> Russia possesses the second-largest fleet of <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">ballistic missile submarines</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[276]</a></sup> and is one of the only three countries operating <a href="/wiki/Strategic_bomber" title="Strategic bomber">strategic bombers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[277]</a></sup> Russia maintains the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">fourth-highest military expenditure</a>, spending $61.7 billion in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[278]</a></sup> In 2021 it was the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_arms_exports" title="List of countries by arms exports">second-largest arms exporter</a>, and had a large and entirely indigenous <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Russia" title="Defense industry of Russia">defence industry</a>, producing most of its own military equipment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[279]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights_and_corruption">Human rights and corruption</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Russia" title="Human rights in Russia">Human rights in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Russia" title="Corruption in Russia">Corruption in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_(Yekaterinburg,_February_24,_2022).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg/220px-Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg/330px-Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg/440px-Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_(Yekaterinburg,_February_24,_2022).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Following the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> in 2022, <a href="/wiki/2022_anti-war_protests_in_Russia" title="2022 anti-war protests in Russia">anti-war protests</a> broke out across Russia. The protests have been met with widespread repression, leading to about 15,000 people being arrested.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-massarrest_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-massarrest-290">[280]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Russia" title="Human rights in Russia">Human rights in Russia</a> have been increasingly criticised by leading democracy and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_group" title="Human rights group">human rights groups</a>. In particular, <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> say that Russia is not democratic and allows few political rights and civil liberties to its citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[282]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2004, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> has ranked Russia as "not free" in its <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a></i> survey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[283]</a></sup> Since 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> has ranked Russia as an "authoritarian regime" in its <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>, ranking it 124th out of 167 countries for 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[284]</a></sup> In regards to <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Russia" title="Media freedom in Russia">media freedom</a>, Russia was ranked 155th out of 180 countries in <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>' <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> for 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[285]</a></sup> The Russian government has been widely criticised by political dissidents and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_defender" title="Human rights defender">human rights activists</a> for <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Russia" title="Elections in Russia">unfair elections</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[286]</a></sup> crackdowns on <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_Vladimir_Putin_in_Russia" title="Opposition to Vladimir Putin in Russia">opposition political parties and protests</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[288]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_undesirable_organizations_law" title="Russian undesirable organizations law">persecution of non-governmental organisations</a> and enforced suppression and <a href="/wiki/List_of_journalists_killed_in_Russia" title="List of journalists killed in Russia">killings of independent journalists</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[291]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_the_Russian_Federation" title="Censorship in the Russian Federation">censorship</a> of mass media and <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Russia" title="Internet censorship in Russia">internet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[292]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocratic</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[293]</a></sup> political system has been variously described as a <a href="/wiki/Kleptocracy" title="Kleptocracy">kleptocracy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[294]</a></sup> an <a href="/wiki/Oligarchy" title="Oligarchy">oligarchy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[295]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Plutocracy" title="Plutocracy">plutocracy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[296]</a></sup> It was the lowest rated European country in <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> for 2021, ranking 136th out of 180 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corruption_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-corruption-307">[297]</a></sup> Russia has a long history of corruption, which is seen as a significant problem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VOA_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-VOA-308">[298]</a></sup> It impacts various sectors, including the economy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[299]</a></sup> business,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[300]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Russia" title="Government of Russia">public administration</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[301]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Russia" title="Law enforcement in Russia">law enforcement</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[302]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Russia" title="Healthcare in Russia">healthcare</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[304]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Russia" title="Education in Russia">education</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[305]</a></sup> and the military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[306]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Russia" title="Economy of Russia">Economy of Russia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Economic history of the Russian Federation">Economic history of the Russian Federation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_Russia" title="Taxation in Russia">Taxation in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1333" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg/220px-Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg/330px-Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg/440px-Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center" title="Moscow International Business Center">Moscow International Business Centre</a> in Moscow. The city has one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">largest urban economies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[307]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Russia has a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[308]</a></sup> with enormous natural resources, particularly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_oil_industry" title="Russian oil industry">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Russia" title="Natural gas in Russia">natural gas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[309]</a></sup> It has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eleventh-largest economy</a> by nominal GDP and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">sixth-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>. The large <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sector</a> accounts for 62% of total GDP, followed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" title="Industrial sector">industrial sector</a> (32%), while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agricultural_sector" title="Agricultural sector">agricultural sector</a> is the smallest, making up only 5% of total GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-6"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> Russia has a low official <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_unemployment_rate" title="List of countries by unemployment rate">unemployment rate</a> of 4.1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[310]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_reserves" title="Foreign exchange reserves">foreign exchange reserves</a> are the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign-exchange_reserves" title="List of countries by foreign-exchange reserves">fifth-largest</a>, worth $540 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[311]</a></sup> It has a labour force of roughly 70 million, which is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_force" title="List of countries by labour force">sixth-largest</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[312]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">thirteenth-largest exporter</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">21st-largest importer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[314]</a></sup> It relies heavily on revenues from oil and gas-related taxes and export tariffs, which accounted for 45% of Russia's federal budget revenues in January 2022,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iea.org_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-iea.org-325">[315]</a></sup> and up to 60% of its exports in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[316]</a></sup> In 2019, the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Natural_Resources_and_Environment_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Russia)">Natural Resources and Environment Ministry</a> estimated the value of natural resources to be 60% of the country's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[317]</a></sup> Russia has one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_external_debt" title="List of countries by external debt">lowest levels of external debt</a> among major economies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[318]</a></sup> although its <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" title="List of countries by income equality">inequality of household income and wealth</a> is one of the highest among developed countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[319]</a></sup> High regional disparity is also an issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>After over a decade of post-Soviet rapid economic growth, backed by high oil-prices and a surge in foreign exchange reserves and investment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Putineconomy_187-1"><a href="#cite_note-Putineconomy-187">[182]</a></sup> Russia's economy was damaged following the start of the Russo-Ukrainian War and the annexation of Crimea in 2014, due to the first wave of <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="International sanctions during the Russo-Ukrainian War">Western sanctions being imposed</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[322]</a></sup> In the aftermath of the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the country has faced <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="International sanctions during the Russo-Ukrainian War">revamped sanctions and corporate boycotts</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[323]</a></sup> becoming the most sanctioned country in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[324]</a></sup> in a move described as an "all-out economic and financial war" to isolate the Russian economy from the Western financial system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sanction1_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-sanction1-197">[192]</a></sup> Due to the <a href="/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Economic impact of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">impact</a>, the Russian government has stopped publishing a raft of economic data since April 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[325]</a></sup> Economists suggest the sanctions will have a long-term effect over the Russian economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[326]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport_and_energy">Transport and energy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Russia" title="Transport in Russia">Transport in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Russia" title="Energy in Russia">Energy in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VL_85-022_container_train.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="825" data-file-width="1154" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/220px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/330px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/440px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:VL_85-022_container_train.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a> is the longest railway line in the world, connecting Moscow to <a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[327]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Russia" title="Rail transport in Russia">Railway transport in Russia</a> is mostly under the control of the state-run <a href="/wiki/Russian_Railways" title="Russian Railways">Russian Railways</a>. The total length of common-used railway tracks is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_rail_transport_network_size" title="List of countries by rail transport network size">third-longest</a>, and exceeds 87,000Â km (54,100Â mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[328]</a></sup> As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Russia has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size" title="List of countries by road network size">fifth-largest road network</a>, with 1.5 millionÂ km of roads,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[329]</a></sup> while its road density is among the world's lowest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[330]</a></sup> Russia's inland waterways are the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_waterways_length" title="List of countries by waterways length">longest</a>, and total 102,000Â km (63,380Â mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[331]</a></sup> Among <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Russia" title="List of airports in Russia">Russia's 1,218 airports</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[332]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Russia" title="List of the busiest airports in Russia">busiest</a> is <a href="/wiki/Sheremetyevo_International_Airport" title="Sheremetyevo International Airport">Sheremetyevo International Airport</a> in Moscow. Russia's largest port is the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Novorossiysk" title="Port of Novorossiysk">Port of Novorossiysk</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krasnodar_Krai" title="Krasnodar Krai">Krasnodar Krai</a> along the Black Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[333]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia has been widely described as an <a href="/wiki/Energy_superpower" title="Energy superpower">energy superpower</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buchanan2021_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-Buchanan2021-344">[334]</a></sup> It has the world's largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">proven gas reserves</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[335]</a></sup> the second-largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coal_reserves" title="Coal reserves">coal reserves</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[336]</a></sup> the eighth-largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[337]</a></sup> and the largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale_reserves" title="Oil shale reserves">oil shale reserves</a> in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[338]</a></sup> Russia is also the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_exports" title="List of countries by natural gas exports">leading natural gas exporter</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[339]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_production" title="List of countries by natural gas production">second-largest natural gas producer</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[340]</a></sup> and the second-largest oil <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_production" title="List of countries by oil production">producer</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_exports" title="List of countries by oil exports">exporter</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[342]</a></sup> Russia's oil and gas production has led to deep economic relationships with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, China, and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">former Soviet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc states</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-354">[344]</a></sup> For example, over the last decade, Russia's share of supplies to total <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (including the United Kingdom) gas demand increased from 25% in 2009 to 32% in the weeks before the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> in February 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_354-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-354">[344]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is committed to the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a>, after joining the pact formally in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[345]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_Russia" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by Russia">Greenhouse gas emissions by Russia</a> are the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions">fourth-largest</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[346]</a></sup> Russia is the world's fourth-largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electricity_producer" title="Electricity producer">electricity producer</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[347]</a></sup> and the ninth-largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_renewable_electricity_production" title="List of countries by renewable electricity production">renewable energy producer</a> in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[348]</a></sup> It was also the world's first country to develop civilian nuclear power, and to construct the world's <a href="/wiki/Obninsk_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant">first nuclear power plant</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[349]</a></sup> Russia was also the world's fourth-largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_by_country" title="Nuclear power by country">nuclear energy producer</a> in 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[350]</a></sup> and was the fifth-largest <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity#World_hydroelectric_capacity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric producer</a> in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[351]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture_and_fishery">Agriculture and fishery</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Russia" title="Agriculture in Russia">Agriculture in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_in_Russia" title="Fishing industry in Russia">Fishing industry in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wheat_Tomsk.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wheat_Tomsk.jpg/220px-Wheat_Tomsk.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wheat_Tomsk.jpg/330px-Wheat_Tomsk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wheat_Tomsk.jpg/440px-Wheat_Tomsk.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wheat_Tomsk.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Wheat in <a href="/wiki/Tomsk_Oblast" title="Tomsk Oblast">Tomsk Oblast</a>, Siberia</div></div></div>
<p>Russia's agriculture sector contributes about 5% of the country's total GDP, although the sector employs about one-eighth of the total labour force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agriculturebritannica_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-agriculturebritannica-362">[352]</a></sup> It has the world's <a href="/wiki/Land_use_statistics_by_country" title="Land use statistics by country">third-largest cultivated area</a>, at 1,265,267 square kilometres (488,522Â sqÂ mi). However, due to the harshness of its environment, about 13.1% of its land is <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_land" title="Agricultural land">agricultural</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-7"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> and only 7.4% of its land is <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[353]</a></sup> The country's agricultural land is considered part of the "<a href="/wiki/Breadbasket" title="Breadbasket">breadbasket</a>" of Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[354]</a></sup> More than one-third of the sown area is devoted to fodder crops, and the remaining farmland is devoted to <a href="/wiki/Nonfood_crop" title="Nonfood crop">industrial crops</a>, vegetables, and fruits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agriculturebritannica_362-1"><a href="#cite_note-agriculturebritannica-362">[352]</a></sup> The main product of Russian farming has always been grain, which occupies considerably more than half of the cropland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agriculturebritannica_362-2"><a href="#cite_note-agriculturebritannica-362">[352]</a></sup> Russia is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_wheat_exports" title="List of countries by wheat exports">largest exporter of wheat</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[356]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_barley_production" title="List of countries by barley production">largest producer of barley</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_producing_countries_of_agricultural_commodities" title="List of largest producing countries of agricultural commodities">buckwheat</a>, among the largest exporters of <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_oil" title="Sunflower oil">sunflower oil</a>, and the leading producer of <a href="/wiki/Fertilizer" title="Fertilizer">fertilizer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>Various analysts of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_adaptation" title="Climate change adaptation">climate change adaptation</a> foresee large opportunities for Russian agriculture during the rest of the 21st century as arability increases in Siberia, which would lead to both internal and external migration to the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climatechange_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-climatechange-368">[358]</a></sup> Owing to its large coastline along three oceans and twelve marginal seas, Russia <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_in_Russia" title="Fishing industry in Russia">maintains</a> the world's <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_by_country" title="Fishing industry by country">sixth-largest fishing industry</a>; capturing nearly 5 million tons of fish in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[359]</a></sup> It is home to the world's finest caviar, the <a href="/wiki/Beluga_(sturgeon)" title="Beluga (sturgeon)">beluga</a>; and produces about one-third of all canned fish, and some one-fourth of the world's total fresh and frozen fish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agriculturebritannica_362-3"><a href="#cite_note-agriculturebritannica-362">[352]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Russia" title="Science and technology in Russia">Science and technology in Russia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_innovation" title="Timeline of Russian innovation">Timeline of Russian innovation</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_scientists" title="List of Russian scientists">List of Russian scientists</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_inventors" title="List of Russian inventors">List of Russian inventors</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_(1787,_RAN).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="597" decoding="async" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/170px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/255px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/340px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_(1787,_RAN).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> (1711â1765), <a href="/wiki/Polymath" title="Polymath">polymath</a> scientist, inventor, poet and artist</div></div></div>
<p>Russia spent about 1% of its GDP on <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> in 2019, with the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_research_and_development_spending" title="List of countries by research and development spending">tenth-highest budget</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[360]</a></sup> It also ranked tenth worldwide in the number of scientific publications in 2020, with roughly 1.3 million papers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[361]</a></sup> Since 1904, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">Nobel Prize</a> were awarded to 26 Soviets and Russians in <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_medicine" title="Nobel Prize in medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Memorial_Prize_in_Economic_Sciences" title="Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences">economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">peace</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[362]</a></sup> Russia ranked 45th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> proposed the <a href="/wiki/Conservation_of_mass" title="Conservation of mass">conservation of mass</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chemical_reactions" title="Chemical reactions">chemical reactions</a>, discovered the <a href="/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Venus" title="Atmosphere of Venus">atmosphere of Venus</a>, and founded modern geology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[364]</a></sup> Since the times of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nikolay_Lobachevsky" title="Nikolay Lobachevsky">Nikolay Lobachevsky</a>, who pioneered the <a href="/wiki/Non-Euclidean_geometry" title="Non-Euclidean geometry">non-Euclidean geometry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pafnuty_Chebyshev" title="Pafnuty Chebyshev">Pafnuty Chebyshev</a>, a prominent tutor; Russian <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_mathematicians" title="List of Russian mathematicians">mathematicians</a> became among the world's most influential.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[365]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dmitry_Mendeleev" title="Dmitry Mendeleev">Dmitry Mendeleev</a> invented the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table" title="Periodic table">Periodic table</a>, the main framework of modern <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[366]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sofya_Kovalevskaya" title="Sofya Kovalevskaya">Sofya Kovalevskaya</a> was a pioneer among <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_women_in_mathematics#19th_Century" title="Timeline of women in mathematics">women in mathematics</a> in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[367]</a></sup> Nine Soviet and Russian mathematicians have been awarded with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fields_Medal_winners" title="Fields Medal winners">Fields Medal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Grigori_Perelman" title="Grigori Perelman">Grigori Perelman</a> was offered the first ever Clay <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Prize_Problems" title="Millennium Prize Problems">Millennium Prize Problems</a> Award for his final proof of the <a href="/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture" title="PoincarÃ© conjecture">PoincarÃ© conjecture</a> in 2002, as well as the Fields Medal in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Alexander_Stepanovich_Popov" title="Alexander Stepanovich Popov">Alexander Popov</a> was among the <a href="/wiki/Invention_of_radio" title="Invention of radio">inventors of radio</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[369]</a></sup> while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nikolai_Basov" title="Nikolai Basov">Nikolai Basov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Prokhorov" title="Alexander Prokhorov">Alexander Prokhorov</a> were co-inventors of <a href="/wiki/Laser" title="Laser">laser</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maser" title="Maser">maser</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[370]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Zhores_Alferov" title="Zhores Alferov">Zhores Alferov</a> contributed significantly to the creation of <a href="/wiki/Heterojunction" title="Heterojunction">modern heterostructure physics and electronics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[371]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Oleg_Losev" title="Oleg Losev">Oleg Losev</a> made crucial contributions in the field of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semiconductor_junction" title="Semiconductor junction">semiconductor junctions</a>, and discovered <a href="/wiki/Light-emitting_diode" title="Light-emitting diode">light-emitting diodes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[372]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vernadsky" title="Vladimir Vernadsky">Vladimir Vernadsky</a> is considered one of the founders of <a href="/wiki/Geochemistry" title="Geochemistry">geochemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biogeochemistry" title="Biogeochemistry">biogeochemistry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radiometric_dating" title="Radiometric dating">radiogeology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[373]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lie_Metchnikoff" title="Ãlie Metchnikoff">Ãlie Metchnikoff</a> is known for his groundbreaking research in <a href="/wiki/Immunology" title="Immunology">immunology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[374]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Pavlov" title="Ivan Pavlov">Ivan Pavlov</a> is known chiefly for his work in <a href="/wiki/Classical_conditioning" title="Classical conditioning">classical conditioning</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[375]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lev_Landau" title="Lev Landau">Lev Landau</a> made fundamental contributions to many areas of <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Vavilov" title="Nikolai Vavilov">Nikolai Vavilov</a> was best known for having identified the <a href="/wiki/Vavilov_center" title="Vavilov center">centres</a> of origin of <a href="/wiki/Horticulture" title="Horticulture">cultivated</a> plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[377]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Trofim_Lysenko" title="Trofim Lysenko">Trofim Lysenko</a> was known mainly for <a href="/wiki/Lysenkoism" title="Lysenkoism">Lysenkoism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[378]</a></sup> Many famous Russian scientists and inventors were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89migr%C3%A9s" title="ÃmigrÃ©s">Ã©migrÃ©s</a>. <a href="/wiki/Igor_Sikorsky" title="Igor Sikorsky">Igor Sikorsky</a> was an <a href="/wiki/List_of_aviation_pioneers" title="List of aviation pioneers">aviation pioneer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[379]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vladimir_Zworykin" title="Vladimir Zworykin">Vladimir Zworykin</a> was the inventor of the <a href="/wiki/Iconoscope" title="Iconoscope">iconoscope</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kinescope" title="Kinescope">kinescope</a> television systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[380]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_Dobzhansky" title="Theodosius Dobzhansky">Theodosius Dobzhansky</a> was the central figure in the field of <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_biology" title="Evolutionary biology">evolutionary biology</a> for his work in shaping the <a href="/wiki/Modern_synthesis_(20th_century)" title="Modern synthesis (20th century)">modern synthesis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[381]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Gamow" title="George Gamow">George Gamow</a> was one of the foremost advocates of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Bang" title="Big Bang">Big Bang</a> theory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[382]</a></sup> Many foreign scientists lived and worked in Russia for a long period, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonard_Euler" title="Leonard Euler">Leonard Euler</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Nobel" title="Alfred Nobel">Alfred Nobel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[384]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Space_exploration">Space exploration</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Russia%26_-39;s_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39;s_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2500" data-file-width="2334" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Russia%26_-39%3Bs_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39%3Bs_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg/220px-Russia%26_-39%3Bs_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39%3Bs_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Russia%26_-39%3Bs_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39%3Bs_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg/330px-Russia%26_-39%3Bs_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39%3Bs_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Russia%26_-39%3Bs_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39%3Bs_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg/440px-Russia%26_-39%3Bs_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39%3Bs_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Russia%26_-39;s_Mir_space_station_is_backdropped_against_Earth%26_-39;s_horizon._Original_from_NASA_._Digitally_enhanced_by_rawpixel._-_41997987775.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a>, Soviet and Russian <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> that operated in <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a> from 1986 to 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[385]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roscosmos" title="Roscosmos">Roscosmos</a> is Russia's national space agency. The country's achievements in the field of <a href="/wiki/Space_technology" title="Space technology">space technology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> can be traced back to <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Tsiolkovsky" title="Konstantin Tsiolkovsky">Konstantin Tsiolkovsky</a>, the father of theoretical <a href="/wiki/Astronautics" title="Astronautics">astronautics</a>, whose works had inspired leading Soviet rocket engineers, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sergey_Korolyov" title="Sergey Korolyov">Sergey Korolyov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valentin_Glushko" title="Valentin Glushko">Valentin Glushko</a>, and many others who contributed to the success of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviet space program</a> in the early stages of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a> and beyond.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 6â7, 333">:â6â7,â333â</span></sup>
</p><p>In 1957, the first Earth-orbiting artificial <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">SputnikÂ 1</a></i>, was launched. In 1961, the first human trip into space was successfully made by <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a>. Many other Soviet and Russian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_exploration_records" title="Space exploration records">space exploration records</a> ensued. In 1963, <a href="/wiki/Valentina_Tereshkova" title="Valentina Tereshkova">Valentina Tereshkova</a> became the first and youngest <a href="/wiki/Women_in_space" title="Women in space">woman in space</a>, having flown a solo mission on <a href="/wiki/Vostok_6" title="Vostok 6">Vostok 6</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[387]</a></sup> In 1965, <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Leonov" title="Alexei Leonov">Alexei Leonov</a> became the first human to conduct a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spacewalk" title="Spacewalk">spacewalk</a>, exiting the <a href="/wiki/Space_capsule" title="Space capsule">space capsule</a> during <a href="/wiki/Voskhod_2" title="Voskhod 2">Voskhod 2</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1957, <a href="/wiki/Laika" title="Laika">Laika</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_dogs" title="Soviet space dogs">Soviet space dog</a>, became the first animal to orbit the Earth, aboard <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_2" title="Sputnik 2">Sputnik 2</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[389]</a></sup> In 1966, <a href="/wiki/Luna_9" title="Luna 9">LunaÂ 9</a> became the first spacecraft to achieve a survivable landing on a <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_object" title="Astronomical object">celestial body</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[390]</a></sup> In 1968, <a href="/wiki/Zond_5" title="Zond 5">Zond 5</a> brought the first Earthlings (two tortoises and other life forms) to circumnavigate the Moon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[391]</a></sup> In 1970, <a href="/wiki/Venera_7" title="Venera 7">VeneraÂ 7</a> became the first spacecraft to land on another planet, <a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[392]</a></sup> In 1971, <a href="/wiki/Mars_3" title="Mars 3">MarsÂ 3</a> became the first spacecraft to land on <a href="/wiki/Mars" title="Mars">Mars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 34â60">:â34â60â</span></sup> During the same period, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lunokhod-1" title="Lunokhod-1">Lunokhod 1</a></i> became the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_exploration_rover" title="Space exploration rover">space exploration rover</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[394]</a></sup> while <i><a href="/wiki/Salyut_1" title="Salyut 1">SalyutÂ 1</a></i> became the world's first <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[395]</a></sup> Russia had 172 active satellites in space in April 2022, the world's third-highest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[396]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Russia" title="Tourism in Russia">Tourism in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2800" data-file-width="4200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg/220px-Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg/330px-Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg/440px-Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof Palace</a> in Saint Petersburg, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">World Tourism Organization</a>, Russia was the sixteenth-most visited country in the world, and the tenth-most visited country in Europe, in 2018, with over 24.6 million visits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unwto_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-unwto-407">[397]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Federal_Agency_for_Tourism_(Russia)" title="Federal Agency for Tourism (Russia)">Federal Agency for Tourism</a>, the number of inbound trips of foreign citizens to Russia amounted to 24.4 million in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[398]</a></sup> Russia's international tourism receipts in 2018 amounted to $11.6 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unwto_407-1"><a href="#cite_note-unwto-407">[397]</a></sup> In 2019, travel and tourism accounted for about 4.8% of country's total GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p>Major tourist routes in Russia include a journey around the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Ring_of_Russia" title="Golden Ring of Russia">Golden Ring of Russia</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theme_route" title="Theme route">theme route</a> of ancient Russian cities, cruises on large rivers such as the Volga, hikes on mountain ranges such as the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains" title="Caucasus Mountains">Caucasus Mountains</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[400]</a></sup> and journeys on the famous <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[401]</a></sup> Russia's most visited and popular landmarks include <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof Palace</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kazan_Kremlin" title="Kazan Kremlin">Kazan Kremlin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Lavra_of_St._Sergius" title="Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius">Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius</a> and Lake Baikal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[402]</a></sup>
</p><p>Moscow, the nation's cosmopolitan capital and historic core, is a bustling <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacity</a>. It retains its classical and Soviet-era architecture; while boasting high art, world class ballet, and <a href="/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center" title="Moscow International Business Center">modern skyscrapers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[403]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, the Imperial capital, is famous for its classical architecture, cathedrals, museums and theatres, <a href="/wiki/White_Nights_Festival" title="White Nights Festival">white nights</a>, criss-crossing rivers and numerous canals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[404]</a></sup> Russia is famed worldwide for its rich museums, such as the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Museum" title="Russian Museum">State Russian</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hermitage_Museum" title="Hermitage Museum">State Hermitage</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Tretyakov_Gallery" title="Tretyakov Gallery">Tretyakov Gallery</a>; and for theatres such as the <a href="/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre" title="Bolshoi Theatre">Bolshoi</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mariinsky_Theatre" title="Mariinsky Theatre">Mariinsky</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin" title="Moscow Kremlin">Moscow Kremlin</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Basil's Cathedral">Saint Basil's Cathedral</a> are among the cultural landmarks of Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[405]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Russia" title="Demographics of Russia">Demographics of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia" title="List of cities and towns in Russia">List of cities and towns in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia_by_population" title="List of cities and towns in Russia by population">List of cities and towns in Russia by population</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Ethnic groups across Russia</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="2820" data-file-width="4836" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/200px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/300px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/400px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;">Ethnic groups in Russia with a population of over 1 million according to the 2010 census.</span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="630" data-file-width="1092" decoding="async" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg/200px-Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg/300px-Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg/400px-Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg.png 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;">Percentage of ethnic Russians by region according to the 2010 census.</span></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Russia is one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population_density" title="List of countries and dependencies by population density">most sparsely populated</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urbanization_by_country" title="Urbanization by country">urbanised</a> countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-8"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> with the vast majority of its population concentrated within its <a href="/wiki/European_Russia" title="European Russia">western part</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[406]</a></sup> It had a population of 142.8 million according to the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Census_(2010)" title="Russian Census (2010)">2010 census</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010Census_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010Census-417">[407]</a></sup> which rose to roughly 145.5 million as of 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gks.ru-popul_13-2"><a href="#cite_note-gks.ru-popul-13">[11]</a></sup> Russia is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">most populous country</a> in Europe, and the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">ninth most populous country</a>, with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_density" title="List of countries by population density">population density</a> of 9 inhabitants per square kilometre (23 per square mile).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 1990s, Russia's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_rate" title="Death rate">death rate</a> has exceeded its <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>, which some analysts have called a <a href="/wiki/Demographic_crisis_of_Russia" title="Demographic crisis of Russia">demographic crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[409]</a></sup> In 2019, the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> across Russia was estimated to be 1.5 children born per woman,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[410]</a></sup> which is below the replacement rate of 2.1, and is one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependencies_by_total_fertility_rate" title="List of sovereign states and dependencies by total fertility rate">lowest fertility rates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[411]</a></sup> Subsequently, the nation has one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_median_age" title="List of countries by median age">oldest populations</a>, with a median age of 40.3 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-9"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> In 2009, it recorded annual population growth for the first time in fifteen years; and since the 2010s, Russia has seen increased population growth due to declining <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_rates" title="Death rates">death rates</a>, increased <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Birth_rates" title="Birth rates">birth rates</a> and increased immigration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[412]</a></sup> However, since 2020, due to excessive deaths from the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Russia" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Russia">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, Russia's population has undergone its largest peacetime decline in history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[413]</a></sup> Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the demographic crisis in the country has deepened,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[414]</a></sup> as the country has faced a renewed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain_drain" title="Brain drain">brain drain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_capital_flight" title="Human capital flight">human capital flight</a> caused by Western mass-sanctions and boycotts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Multinational_state" title="Multinational state">multinational state</a> with many subnational entities associated with different minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[416]</a></sup> There are over <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia" title="Ethnic groups in Russia">193 ethnic groups nationwide</a>. In the 2010 census, roughly 81% of the population were ethnic <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>, and the remaining 19% of the population were ethnic minorities;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[417]</a></sup> while over four-fifths of Russia's population was of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Europe" title="Ethnic groups of Europe">European descent</a>âof which the vast majority were <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">Slavs</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[418]</a></sup> with a substantial minority of <a href="/wiki/Finnic_peoples" title="Finnic peoples">Finnic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic peoples</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[419]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[420]</a></sup> According to the United Nations, Russia's <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Russia" title="Immigration to Russia">immigrant population</a> is the world's third-largest, numbering over 11.6 million;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[421]</a></sup> most of which are from <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_states" title="Post-Soviet states">post-Soviet states</a>, mainly <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Russia" title="Ukrainians in Russia">Ukrainians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[422]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Russia" title="Languages of Russia">Languages of Russia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:342px;max-width:342px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Minority languages across Russia</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:135px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic,_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_(en).png"><img alt="" data-file-height="2036" data-file-width="3245" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/215px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/323px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/430px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 2x" width="215"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Altaic_languages" title="Altaic languages">Altaic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">Uralic languages</a> spoken across Russia</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:121px;max-width:121px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:135px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1111" data-file-width="977" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/119px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/179px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/238px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png 2x" width="119"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a> is <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus" title="Peoples of the Caucasus">ethno</a>-<a href="/wiki/North_Caucasian_languages" title="North Caucasian languages">linguistically</a> diverse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[424]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Russian is the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official</a> and the predominantly spoken language in Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Russian_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-Russian-4">[3]</a></sup> It is the most spoken <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">native language</a> in Europe, the most geographically widespread language of Eurasia, as well as the world's most widely spoken <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">Slavic language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-language_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-language-435">[425]</a></sup> Russian is one of two official languages aboard the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[426]</a></sup> as well as one of the six <a href="/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations" title="Official languages of the United Nations">official languages of the United Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-language_435-1"><a href="#cite_note-language-435">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Multilingualism#Europe" title="Multilingualism">multilingual</a> nation; approximately 100â150 minority languages are spoken across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[428]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Census_(2010)" title="Russian Census (2010)">Russian Census of 2010</a>, 137.5Â million across the country spoke Russian, 4.3Â million spoke <a href="/wiki/Tatar_language" title="Tatar language">Tatar</a>, and 1.1Â million spoke <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[429]</a></sup> The constitution gives the country's individual republics the right to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_official_languages_in_Russia" title="List of official languages in Russia">establish their own state languages</a> in addition to Russian, as well as guarantee its citizens the right to preserve their native language and to create conditions for its study and development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[430]</a></sup> However, various experts have claimed Russia's linguistic diversity is rapidly declining due to <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_Russia" title="List of endangered languages in Russia">many languages becoming endangered</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[432]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Russia" title="Religion in Russia">Religion in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2128" data-file-width="2105" decoding="async" height="222" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg/220px-Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg/330px-Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg/440px-Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Basil's Cathedral">Saint Basil's Cathedral</a> in Moscow is the most iconic religious architecture of Russia.</div></div></div>
<p>Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> by constitution, and its largest religion is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Christianity" title="Eastern Orthodox Christianity">Eastern Orthodox Christianity</a>, chiefly represented by the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-7">[5]</a></sup> Orthodox Christianity, together with <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">Paganism</a> (either preserved or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modern_Paganism" title="Modern Paganism">revived</a>), are recognised by Russian law as the traditional religions of the country, part of its "historical heritage".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[434]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2020_amendments_to_the_Constitution_of_Russia" title="2020 amendments to the Constitution of Russia">amendments of 2020 to the constitution</a> added, in the Article 67, the continuity of the Russian state in history based on preserving "the memory of the ancestors" and general "ideals and belief in God" which the ancestors conveyed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[435]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the collapse of the Soviet Union, there was a renewal of religions in Russia, with the revival of the traditional faiths and the emergence of new forms within the traditional faiths as well as many <a href="/wiki/New_religious_movement" title="New religious movement">new religious movements</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[437]</a></sup> Islam is the second-largest religion in Russia, and is the traditional religion among the majority of the <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus" title="Peoples of the Caucasus">peoples of the North Caucasus</a>, and among some <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic peoples</a> scattered along the <a href="/wiki/Idel-Ural" title="Idel-Ural">Volga-Ural</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_7-2"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-7">[5]</a></sup> Large populations of Buddhists are found in <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Kalmykia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buryatia" title="Buryatia">Buryatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zabaykalsky_Krai" title="Zabaykalsky Krai">Zabaykalsky Krai</a>, and they are the vast majority of the population in <a href="/wiki/Tuva" title="Tuva">Tuva</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_7-3"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-7">[5]</a></sup> Many Russians practise other religions, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rodnovery" title="Rodnovery">Rodnovery</a> (Slavic Neopaganism),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[438]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Assianism" title="Assianism">Assianism</a> (Scythian Neopaganism),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[439]</a></sup> other ethnic Paganisms, and inter-Pagan movements such as <a href="/wiki/Ringing_Cedars%27_Anastasianism" title="Ringing Cedars'
