Anastasianism">Ringing Cedars' Anastasianism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[440]</a></sup> various movements of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[441]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siberian_shamanism" title="Siberian shamanism">Siberian shamanism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[442]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tengrism" title="Tengrism">Tengrism</a>, various <a href="/wiki/Neo-Theosophy" title="Neo-Theosophy">Neo-Theosophical</a> movements such as <a href="/wiki/Roerichism" title="Roerichism">Roerichism</a>, and other faiths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[443]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[444]</a></sup> Some religious minorities have faced oppression and some have been banned in the country;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[445]</a></sup> notably, in 2017 the <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> were outlawed in Russia, facing persecution ever since, after having been declared an "extremist" and "nontraditional" faith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, the research organisation Sreda, in cooperation with the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Justice (Russia)">Ministry of Justice</a>, published the Arena Atlas, an adjunct to the 2010 census, enumerating in detail the religious populations and nationalities of Russia, based on a large-sample country-wide survey. The results showed that 47.3% of Russians declared themselves Christians â including 41% Russian Orthodox, 1.5% simply Orthodox or members of non-Russian Orthodox churches, 4.1% unaffiliated Christians, and less than 1% <a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">Old Believers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholics</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestants" title="Protestants">Protestants</a> â 25% were <a href="/wiki/Spiritual_but_not_religious" title="Spiritual but not religious">believers without affiliation to any specific religion</a>, 13% were <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a>, 6.5% were Muslims,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlasIslam_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlasIslam-6">[b]</a></sup> 1.2% were followers of "traditional religions honouring gods and ancestors" (Rodnovery, other Paganisms, Siberian shamanism and Tengrism), 0.5% were Buddhists, 0.1% were <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">religious Jews</a> and 0.1% were Hindus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_7-5"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-7">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Russia" title="Education in Russia">Education in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3,_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2610" data-file-width="3946" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/330px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/440px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3,_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a>, the most prestigious educational institution in Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[447]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Russia has an adult <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literate" title="Literate">literacy rate</a> of 100%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[448]</a></sup> and has <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory education</a> for a duration of 11 years, exclusively for children aged 7 to 17â18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nuffic_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nuffic-459">[449]</a></sup> It grants <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">free education</a> to its citizens by constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CEPES_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-CEPES-460">[450]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Education (Russia)">Ministry of Education of Russia</a> is responsible for primary and secondary education, as well as vocational education; while the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Science_and_Higher_Education_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Science and Higher Education (Russia)">Ministry of Education and Science of Russia</a> is responsible for science and higher education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nuffic_459-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nuffic-459">[449]</a></sup> Regional authorities regulate education within their jurisdictions within the prevailing framework of federal laws. Russia is among the world's most educated countries, and has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_tertiary_education_attainment" title="List of countries by tertiary education attainment">sixth-highest proportion</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary-level graduates</a> in terms of percentage of population, at 62.1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[451]</a></sup> It spent roughly 4.7% of its GDP on education in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[452]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pre-school" title="Pre-school">pre-school</a> education system is highly developed and optional,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[453]</a></sup> some four-fifths of children aged 3 to 6 attend day nurseries or kindergartens. Primary school is compulsory for eleven years, starting from age 6 to 7, and leads to a basic general education certificate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nuffic_459-2"><a href="#cite_note-Nuffic-459">[449]</a></sup> An additional two or three years of schooling are required for the secondary-level certificate, and some seven-eighths of Russians continue their education past this level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Educationb_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-Educationb-464">[454]</a></sup>
</p><p>Admission to an institute of higher education is selective and highly competitive:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CEPES_460-1"><a href="#cite_note-CEPES-460">[450]</a></sup> first-degree courses usually take five years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Educationb_464-1"><a href="#cite_note-Educationb-464">[454]</a></sup> The oldest and largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_institutions_of_higher_education_in_Russia" title="List of institutions of higher education in Russia">universities</a> in Russia are <a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_State_University" title="Saint Petersburg State University">Saint Petersburg State University</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[455]</a></sup> There are ten highly prestigious <a href="/wiki/Template:Federal_universities_of_Russia" title="Template:Federal universities of Russia">federal universities</a> across the country. Russia was the world's fifth-leading destination for <a href="/wiki/International_student" title="International student">international students</a> in 2019, hosting roughly 300 thousand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[456]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Russia" title="Healthcare in Russia">Healthcare in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Metallurg_Sochi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Metallurg_Sochi.jpg/220px-Metallurg_Sochi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Metallurg_Sochi.jpg/330px-Metallurg_Sochi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Metallurg_Sochi.jpg/440px-Metallurg_Sochi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Metallurg_Sochi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Metallurg, a Soviet-era <a href="/wiki/Sanatorium" title="Sanatorium">sanatorium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[457]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Russia, by constitution, guarantees free, <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> for all Russian citizens, through a compulsory state health insurance program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[458]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Health (Russia)">Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation</a> oversees the Russian public healthcare system, and the sector employs more than two million people. Federal regions also have their own departments of health that oversee local administration. A separate private health insurance plan is needed to access private healthcare in Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[459]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia spent 5.65% of its GDP on healthcare in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[460]</a></sup> Its healthcare expenditure is notably lower than other developed nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[461]</a></sup> Russia has one of the world's most female-biased <a href="/wiki/Human_sex_ratio" title="Human sex ratio">sex ratios</a>, with 0.859 males to every female,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-10"><a href="#cite_note-cia-8">[6]</a></sup> due to its high male <a href="/wiki/Mortality_rate" title="Mortality rate">mortality rate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[462]</a></sup> In 2019, the overall <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy in Russia</a> at birth was 73.2 years (68.2 years for males and 78.0 years for females),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[463]</a></sup> and it had a very low <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality rate</a> (5 per 1,000 <a href="/wiki/Live_birth_(human)" title="Live birth (human)">live births</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[464]</a></sup>
</p><p>The principle cause of death in Russia are cardiovascular diseases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[465]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">Obesity</a> is a prevalent health issue in Russia; 61.1% of Russian adults were overweight or obese in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[466]</a></sup> However, Russia's historically high <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_consumption_in_Russia" title="Alcohol consumption in Russia">alcohol consumption rate</a> is the biggest health issue in the country,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[467]</a></sup> as it remains <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_alcohol_consumption_per_capita" title="List of countries by alcohol consumption per capita">one of the world's highest</a>, despite a stark decrease in the last decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[468]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tobacco_consumption_by_country" title="Tobacco consumption by country">Smoking</a> is another health issue in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[469]</a></sup>  The country's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_suicide_rate" title="List of countries by suicide rate">high suicide rate</a>, although <a href="/wiki/Suicide_in_Russia" title="Suicide in Russia">on the decline</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[470]</a></sup> remains a significant social issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[471]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_culture" title="Russian culture">Russian culture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5598" data-file-width="6728" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg/220px-Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg/330px-Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg/440px-Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre" title="Bolshoi Theatre">Bolshoi Theatre</a> in Moscow, at night</div></div></div>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_culture" title="Russian culture">Russian culture</a> has been formed by the nation's history, its geographical location and its vast expanse, religious and social traditions, and <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western influence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[472]</a></sup> Russian <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">writers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" title="Russian philosophy">philosophers</a> have played an important role in the development of <a href="/wiki/Western_literature" title="Western literature">European literature</a> and thought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-literature1_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-literature1-483">[473]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[474]</a></sup> The Russians have also greatly influenced classical music,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[475]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_ballet" title="Russian ballet">ballet</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[476]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Russia" title="Sport in Russia">sport</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sport_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-sport-487">[477]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_artists" title="List of Russian artists">painting</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[478]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Russia" title="Cinema of Russia">cinema</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cinematic_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-cinematic-489">[479]</a></sup> The nation has also made pioneering contributions to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_inventions_and_technology_records" title="Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records">science and technology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[481]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is home to <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Russia" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Russia">30 UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>, 19 out of which are cultural; while 27 more sites lie on the tentative list.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[482]</a></sup> The large global <a href="/wiki/Russian_diaspora" title="Russian diaspora">Russian diaspora</a> has also played a major role in spreading Russian culture throughout the world. Russia's <a href="/wiki/List_of_cultural_icons_of_Russia" title="List of cultural icons of Russia">national symbol</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Double-headed_eagle" title="Double-headed eagle">double-headed eagle</a>, dates back to the Tsardom period, and is featured in its <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Russia" title="Coat of arms of Russia">coat of arms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_heraldry" title="Russian heraldry">heraldry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muscovy_63-4"><a href="#cite_note-Muscovy-63">[59]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Bear" title="Russian Bear">Russian Bear</a> and <a href="/wiki/Personification_of_Russia" title="Personification of Russia">Mother Russia</a> are often used as <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personifications</a> of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[483]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[484]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Matryoshka_dolls" title="Matryoshka dolls">Matryoshka dolls</a> are considered a cultural icon of Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[485]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays">Holidays</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Russia" title="Public holidays in Russia">Public holidays in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg/330px-%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg/440px-%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_Sails_(tradition)" title="Scarlet Sails (tradition)">Scarlet Sails</a> being celebrated along the <a href="/wiki/Neva" title="Neva">Neva</a> in Saint Petersburg</div></div></div>
<p>Russia has eightâpublic, patriotic, and religiousâofficial holidays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[486]</a></sup> The year starts with New Year's Day on 1 January, soon followed by <a href="/wiki/Christmas_in_Russia" title="Christmas in Russia">Russian Orthodox Christmas</a> on 7 January; the two are the country's most popular holidays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[487]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Defender_of_the_Fatherland_Day" title="Defender of the Fatherland Day">Defender of the Fatherland Day</a>, dedicated to men, is celebrated on 23 February.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[488]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/International_Women%27s_Day" title="International Women's Day">International Women's Day</a> on 8 March, gained momentum in Russia during the Soviet era. The annual celebration of women has become so popular, especially among Russian men, that Moscow's flower vendors often see profits of "15 times"  more than other holidays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[489]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/May_Day#Russia" title="May Day">Spring and Labor Day</a>, originally a Soviet era holiday dedicated to workers, is celebrated on 1 May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[490]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(Russia)" title="Victory Day (Russia)">Victory Day</a>, which honors Soviet victory over Nazi Germany and the <a href="/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Europe" title="End of World War II in Europe">End of World War II in Europe</a>, is celebrated as an annual <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Victory_Day_Parade" title="Moscow Victory Day Parade">large parade</a> in Moscow's Red Square;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[491]</a></sup> and marks the famous <a href="/wiki/Immortal_Regiment" title="Immortal Regiment">Immortal Regiment</a> civil event.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[492]</a></sup> Other patriotic holidays include <a href="/wiki/Russia_Day" title="Russia Day">Russia Day</a> on 12 June, celebrated to commemorate Russia's <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_State_Sovereignty_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Declaration of State Sovereignty of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">declaration of sovereignty</a> from the collapsing Soviet Union;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[493]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Unity_Day_(Russia)" title="Unity Day (Russia)">Unity Day</a> on 4 November, commemorating the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moscow_(1612)" title="Battle of Moscow (1612)">1612 uprising</a> which marked the end of the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Muscovite_War_(1609%E2%80%931618)" title="PolishâMuscovite War (1609â1618)">Polish occupation of Moscow</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[494]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are many popular non-public holidays. <a href="/wiki/Old_New_Year" title="Old New Year">Old New Year</a> is celebrated on 14 January.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[495]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maslenitsa" title="Maslenitsa">Maslenitsa</a> is an ancient and popular East Slavic folk holiday.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[496]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cosmonautics_Day" title="Cosmonautics Day">Cosmonautics Day</a> on 12 April, in tribute to the first human trip into space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[497]</a></sup> Two major Christian holidays are Easter and <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Sunday" title="Trinity Sunday">Trinity Sunday</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[498]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_architecture">Art and architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_artists" title="Russian artists">Russian artists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_architecture" title="Russian architecture">Russian architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_architects" title="List of Russian architects">List of Russian architects</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:220px;max-width:220px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:153px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="21059" data-file-width="30000" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/218px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/327px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/436px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="218"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;"><a href="/wiki/Karl_Bryullov" title="Karl Bryullov">Karl Bryullov</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii" title="The Last Day of Pompeii">The Last Day of Pompeii</a></i> (1833)</span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:220px;max-width:220px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:130px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="5000" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg/218px-Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg/327px-Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg/436px-Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg 2x" width="218"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;">The <a href="/wiki/Winter_Palace" title="Winter Palace">Winter Palace</a> served as the <a href="/wiki/Official_residence" title="Official residence">official residence</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_all_the_Russias" title="Emperor of all the Russias">Emperor of Russia</a></span></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Early Russian painting is represented in <a href="/wiki/Russian_icons" title="Russian icons">icons</a> and vibrant <a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">frescos</a>. In the early 15th-century, the master icon painter <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Rublev" title="Andrei Rublev">Andrei Rublev</a> created some of Russia's most treasured religious art.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Art_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-Art-509">[499]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Arts" title="Russian Academy of Arts">Russian Academy of Arts</a>, which was established in 1757, to train Russian artists, brought Western techniques of secular painting to Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earlyimperial_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-earlyimperial-78">[74]</a></sup> In the 18th century, academicians <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Argunov" title="Ivan Argunov">Ivan Argunov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Levitzky" title="Dmitry Levitzky">Dmitry Levitzky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Borovikovsky" title="Vladimir Borovikovsky">Vladimir Borovikovsky</a> became influential.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[500]</a></sup> The early 19th century saw many prominent paintings by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karl_Briullov" title="Karl Briullov">Karl Briullov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Andreyevich_Ivanov" title="Alexander Andreyevich Ivanov">Alexander Ivanov</a>, both of whom were known for <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantic</a> historical canvases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[502]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Aivazovsky" title="Ivan Aivazovsky">Ivan Aivazovsky</a>, another Romantic painter, is considered one of the greatest masters of <a href="/wiki/Marine_art" title="Marine art">marine art</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[503]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1860s, a group of critical <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">realists</a> (<a href="/wiki/Peredvizhniki" title="Peredvizhniki">Peredvizhniki</a>), led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivan_Kramskoy" title="Ivan Kramskoy">Ivan Kramskoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilya_Repin" title="Ilya Repin">Ilya Repin</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vasiliy_Perov" title="Vasiliy Perov">Vasiliy Perov</a> broke with the academy, and portrayed the many-sided aspects of social life in paintings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[504]</a></sup> The turn of the 20th century saw the rise of <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">symbolism</a>; represented by <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Vrubel" title="Mikhail Vrubel">Mikhail Vrubel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Roerich" title="Nicholas Roerich">Nicholas Roerich</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[505]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[506]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_avant-garde" title="Russian avant-garde">Russian avant-garde</a> flourished from approximately 1890 to 1930; and globally influential artists from this era were <a href="/wiki/El_Lissitzky" title="El Lissitzky">El Lissitzky</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[507]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kazimir_Malevich" title="Kazimir Malevich">Kazimir Malevich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natalia_Goncharova" title="Natalia Goncharova">Natalia Goncharova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky" title="Wassily Kandinsky">Wassily Kandinsky</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marc_Chagall" title="Marc Chagall">Marc Chagall</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[508]</a></sup>
</p><p>The history of <a href="/wiki/Russian_architecture" title="Russian architecture">Russian architecture</a> begins with early woodcraft buildings of ancient Slavs, and the <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Architecture of Kievan Rus'">church architecture of Kievan Rus'</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[509]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus'">Christianization of Kievan Rus'</a>, for several centuries it was influenced predominantly by <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture#Legacy" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[510]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aristotle_Fioravanti" title="Aristotle Fioravanti">Aristotle Fioravanti</a> and other Italian architects brought <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> trends into Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[511]</a></sup> The 16th-century saw the development of the unique <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tent-like_church" title="Tent-like church">tent-like churches</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Onion_dome" title="Onion dome">onion dome</a> design, which is a distinctive feature of Russian architecture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[512]</a></sup> In the 17th-century, the "fiery style" of ornamentation flourished in Moscow and <a href="/wiki/Yaroslavl" title="Yaroslavl">Yaroslavl</a>, gradually paving the way for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naryshkin_baroque" title="Naryshkin baroque">Naryshkin baroque</a> of the 1680s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[513]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the reforms of Peter the Great, Russia's architecture became influenced by Western European styles. The 18th-century taste for <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">Rococo</a> architecture led to the <a href="/wiki/Elizabethan_Baroque" title="Elizabethan Baroque">splendid works</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bartolomeo_Rastrelli" title="Bartolomeo Rastrelli">Bartolomeo Rastrelli</a> and his followers. The most influential Russian architects of the eighteenth century; <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Bazhenov" title="Vasily Bazhenov">Vasily Bazhenov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matvey_Kazakov" title="Matvey Kazakov">Matvey Kazakov</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Starov" title="Ivan Starov">Ivan Starov</a>, created lasting monuments in Moscow and Saint Petersburg and established a base for the more Russian forms that followed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Art_509-1"><a href="#cite_note-Art-509">[499]</a></sup> During the reign of Catherine the Great, Saint Petersburg was transformed into an outdoor museum of <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical architecture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[514]</a></sup> Under Alexander I, <a href="/wiki/Empire_style" title="Empire style">Empire style</a> became the <i>de facto</i> architectural style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[515]</a></sup> The second half of the 19th-century was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Byzantine_architecture_in_the_Russian_Empire" title="Neo-Byzantine architecture in the Russian Empire">Neo-Byzantine</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Revival" title="Russian Revival">Russian Revival</a> style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[516]</a></sup> In early 20th-century, <a href="/wiki/Russian_neoclassical_revival" title="Russian neoclassical revival">Russian neoclassical revival</a> became a trend.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[517]</a></sup> Prevalent styles of the late 20th-century were <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau_architecture_in_Russia" title="Art Nouveau architecture in Russia">Art Nouveau</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[518]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Constructivism_(art)" title="Constructivism (art)">Constructivism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[519]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Stalinist_architecture" title="Stalinist architecture">Socialist Classicism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[520]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Russia" title="Music of Russia">Music of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_(1840-1893).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2466" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg/170px-Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg/255px-Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg/340px-Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_(1840-1893).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a> (1840â1893), in a 1893 painting by <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Dmitriyevich_Kuznetsov_(painter)" title="Nikolai Dmitriyevich Kuznetsov (painter)">Nikolai Dmitriyevich Kuznetsov</a></div></div></div>
<p>Until the 18th-century, music in Russia consisted mainly of church music and folk songs and dances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Music_531-0"><a href="#cite_note-Music-531">[521]</a></sup> In the 19th-century, it was defined by the tension between classical composer <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Glinka" title="Mikhail Glinka">Mikhail Glinka</a> along with other members of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Mighty_Handful" title="The Mighty Handful">The Mighty Handful</a>, who were later succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Belyayev_circle" title="Belyayev circle">Belyayev circle</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[522]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Musical_Society" title="Russian Musical Society">Russian Musical Society</a> led by composers <a href="/wiki/Anton_Rubinstein" title="Anton Rubinstein">Anton</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nikolay_Rubinstein" title="Nikolay Rubinstein">Nikolay Rubinstein</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[523]</a></sup> The later tradition of <a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a>, one of the greatest composers of the Romantic era, was continued into the 20th century by <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Rachmaninoff" title="Sergei Rachmaninoff">Sergei Rachmaninoff</a>, one of the last great representatives of Romanticism in <a href="/wiki/Russian_classical_music" title="Russian classical music">Russian</a> and European classical music. World-renowned composers of the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Scriabin" title="Alexander Scriabin">Alexander Scriabin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Glazunov" title="Alexander Glazunov">Alexander Glazunov</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Music_531-1"><a href="#cite_note-Music-531">[521]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky" title="Igor Stravinsky">Igor Stravinsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Prokofiev" title="Sergei Prokofiev">Sergei Prokofiev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Shostakovich" title="Dmitri Shostakovich">Dmitri Shostakovich</a>, and later <a href="/wiki/Edison_Denisov" title="Edison Denisov">Edison Denisov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sofia_Gubaidulina" title="Sofia Gubaidulina">Sofia Gubaidulina</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-music2_534-0"><a href="#cite_note-music2-534">[524]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Georgy_Sviridov" title="Georgy Sviridov">Georgy Sviridov</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[525]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Schnittke" title="Alfred Schnittke">Alfred Schnittke</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-music2_534-1"><a href="#cite_note-music2-534">[524]</a></sup>
</p><p>Soviet and Russian conservatories have turned out generations of world-renowned soloists. Among the best known are violinists <a href="/wiki/David_Oistrakh" title="David Oistrakh">David Oistrakh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gidon_Kremer" title="Gidon Kremer">Gidon Kremer</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[526]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[527]</a></sup> cellist <a href="/wiki/Mstislav_Rostropovich" title="Mstislav Rostropovich">Mstislav Rostropovich</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[528]</a></sup> pianists <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Horowitz" title="Vladimir Horowitz">Vladimir Horowitz</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[529]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sviatoslav_Richter" title="Sviatoslav Richter">Sviatoslav Richter</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[530]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Emil_Gilels" title="Emil Gilels">Emil Gilels</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[531]</a></sup> and vocalist <a href="/wiki/Galina_Vishnevskaya" title="Galina Vishnevskaya">Galina Vishnevskaya</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[532]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Soviet era, <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">popular music</a> also produced a number of renowned figures, such as the two <a href="/wiki/Bard_(Soviet_Union)" title="Bard (Soviet Union)">balladeers</a>â<a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vysotsky" title="Vladimir Vysotsky">Vladimir Vysotsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulat_Okudzhava" title="Bulat Okudzhava">Bulat Okudzhava</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-music2_534-2"><a href="#cite_note-music2-534">[524]</a></sup> and performers such as <a href="/wiki/Alla_Pugacheva" title="Alla Pugacheva">Alla Pugacheva</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[533]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">Jazz</a>, even with sanctions from Soviet authorities, flourished and evolved into one of the country's most popular musical forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-music2_534-3"><a href="#cite_note-music2-534">[524]</a></sup> By the 1980s, <a href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_Russia" title="Rock music in Russia">rock music</a> became popular across Russia, and produced bands such as <a href="/wiki/Aria_(band)" title="Aria (band)">Aria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aquarium_(band)" title="Aquarium (band)">Aquarium</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[534]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/DDT_(band)" title="DDT (band)">DDT</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[535]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kino_(band)" title="Kino (band)">Kino</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[536]</a></sup> the latter's leader <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Tsoi" title="Viktor Tsoi">Viktor Tsoi</a>, was in particular, a gigantic figure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[537]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_pop" title="Russian pop">Pop music</a> has continued to flourish in Russia since the 1960s, with globally famous acts such as <a href="/wiki/T.A.T.u." title="T.A.T.u.">t.A.T.u.</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[538]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:138px;max-width:138px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:184px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_(1844-1930)_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_(1887).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1508" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/136px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/204px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/272px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg 2x" width="136"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;"><a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> (1828â1910), is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time, with works such as <i><a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace" title="War and Peace">War and Peace</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[539]</a></sup></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:150px;max-width:150px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:184px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/148px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/222px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/296px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="148"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;"><a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Dostoevsky" title="Fyodor Dostoevsky">Fyodor Dostoevsky</a> (1821â1881), one of the great novelists of all time, whose masterpieces include <i><a href="/wiki/Crime_and_Punishment" title="Crime and Punishment">Crime and Punishment</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[540]</a></sup></span></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a> is considered to be among the world's most influential and developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-literature1_483-1"><a href="#cite_note-literature1-483">[473]</a></sup> It can be traced to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, when epics and chronicles in <a href="/wiki/Old_East_Slavic" title="Old East Slavic">Old East Slavic</a> were composed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[541]</a></sup> By the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>, literature had grown in importance, with works from <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Denis_Fonvizin" title="Denis Fonvizin">Denis Fonvizin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gavrila_Derzhavin" title="Gavrila Derzhavin">Gavrila Derzhavin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Karamzin" title="Nikolay Karamzin">Nikolay Karamzin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-literature_552-0"><a href="#cite_note-literature-552">[542]</a></sup> From the early 1830s, during the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Russian_Poetry" title="Golden Age of Russian Poetry">Golden Age of Russian Poetry</a>, literature underwent an astounding golden age in poetry, prose and drama.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[543]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a> permitted a flowering of poetic talent: <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Zhukovsky" title="Vasily Zhukovsky">Vasily Zhukovsky</a> and later his protÃ©gÃ© <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a> came to the fore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[544]</a></sup> Following Pushkin's footsteps, a new generation of poets were born, including <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lermontov" title="Mikhail Lermontov">Mikhail Lermontov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Nekrasov" title="Nikolay Nekrasov">Nikolay Nekrasov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aleksey_Konstantinovich_Tolstoy" title="Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy">Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Tyutchev" title="Fyodor Tyutchev">Fyodor Tyutchev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afanasy_Fet" title="Afanasy Fet">Afanasy Fet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-literature_552-1"><a href="#cite_note-literature-552">[542]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first great Russian novelist was <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Gogol" title="Nikolai Gogol">Nikolai Gogol</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[545]</a></sup> Then came <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Turgenev" title="Ivan Turgenev">Ivan Turgenev</a>, who mastered both short stories and novels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[546]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fyodor_Dostoyevsky" title="Fyodor Dostoyevsky">Fyodor Dostoevsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> soon became internationally renowned. <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Goncharov" title="Ivan Goncharov">Ivan Goncharov</a> is remembered mainly for his novel <a href="/wiki/Oblomov" title="Oblomov">Oblomov</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[547]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Saltykov-Shchedrin" title="Mikhail Saltykov-Shchedrin">Mikhail Saltykov-Shchedrin</a> wrote prose satire,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[548]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Leskov" title="Nikolai Leskov">Nikolai Leskov</a> is best remembered for his shorter fiction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[549]</a></sup> In the second half of the century <a href="/wiki/Anton_Chekhov" title="Anton Chekhov">Anton Chekhov</a> excelled in short stories and became a leading dramatist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[550]</a></sup> Other important 19th-century developments included the fabulist <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Krylov" title="Ivan Krylov">Ivan Krylov</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[551]</a></sup> non-fiction writers such as the critic <a href="/wiki/Vissarion_Belinsky" title="Vissarion Belinsky">Vissarion Belinsky</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[552]</a></sup> and playwrights such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Griboyedov" title="Aleksandr Griboyedov">Aleksandr Griboyedov</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Ostrovsky" title="Aleksandr Ostrovsky">Aleksandr Ostrovsky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[553]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[554]</a></sup> The beginning of the 20th century ranks as the <a href="/wiki/Silver_Age_of_Russian_Poetry" title="Silver Age of Russian Poetry">Silver Age of Russian Poetry</a>. This era had poets such as <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Blok" title="Alexander Blok">Alexander Blok</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anna_Akhmatova" title="Anna Akhmatova">Anna Akhmatova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boris_Pasternak" title="Boris Pasternak">Boris Pasternak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Balmont" title="Konstantin Balmont">Konstantin Balmont</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[555]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marina_Tsvetaeva" title="Marina Tsvetaeva">Marina Tsvetaeva</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Mayakovsky" title="Vladimir Mayakovsky">Vladimir Mayakovsky</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Osip_Mandelshtam" title="Osip Mandelshtam">Osip Mandelshtam</a>. It also produced some first-rate novelists and short-story writers, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Kuprin" title="Aleksandr Kuprin">Aleksandr Kuprin</a>, Nobel Prize winner <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Bunin" title="Ivan Bunin">Ivan Bunin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Andreyev" title="Leonid Andreyev">Leonid Andreyev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Zamyatin" title="Yevgeny Zamyatin">Yevgeny Zamyatin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Merezhkovsky" title="Dmitry Merezhkovsky">Dmitry Merezhkovsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Bely" title="Andrei Bely">Andrei Bely</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-literature_552-2"><a href="#cite_note-literature-552">[542]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the Russian Revolution of 1917, Russian literature split into Soviet and <a href="/wiki/White_%C3%A9migr%C3%A9" title="White Ã©migrÃ©">white Ã©migrÃ©</a> parts. In the 1930s, <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">Socialist realism</a> became the predominant trend in Russia. Its leading figure was <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Gorky" title="Maxim Gorky">Maxim Gorky</a>, who laid the foundations of this style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-566"><a href="#cite_note-566">[556]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bulgakov" title="Mikhail Bulgakov">Mikhail Bulgakov</a> was one of the leading writers of the Soviet era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[557]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nikolay_Ostrovsky" title="Nikolay Ostrovsky">Nikolay Ostrovsky</a>'s novel <a href="/wiki/How_the_Steel_Was_Tempered" title="How the Steel Was Tempered">How the Steel Was Tempered</a> has been among the most successful works of Russian literature. Influential Ã©migrÃ© writers include <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Nabokov" title="Vladimir Nabokov">Vladimir Nabokov</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[558]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Asimov" title="Isaac Asimov">Isaac Asimov</a>; who was considered one of the "Big Three" science fiction writers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[559]</a></sup> Some writers dared to oppose Soviet ideology, such as Nobel Prize-winning novelist <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Solzhenitsyn" title="Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn">Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn</a>, who wrote about life in the Gulag camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-570"><a href="#cite_note-570">[560]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a> has been greatly influential. <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Herzen" title="Alexander Herzen">Alexander Herzen</a> is known as one of the fathers of <a href="/wiki/Agrarianism" title="Agrarianism">agrarian</a> <a href="/wiki/Populism" title="Populism">populism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[561]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bakunin" title="Mikhail Bakunin">Mikhail Bakunin</a> is referred to as the father of <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[562]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Kropotkin" title="Peter Kropotkin">Peter Kropotkin</a> was the most important theorist of <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-communism" title="Anarcho-communism">anarcho-communism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[563]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bakhtin" title="Mikhail Bakhtin">Mikhail Bakhtin</a>'s writings have significantly inspired scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574"><a href="#cite_note-574">[564]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Helena_Blavatsky" title="Helena Blavatsky">Helena Blavatsky</a> gained international following as the leading theoretician of <a href="/wiki/Theosophy" title="Theosophy">Theosophy</a>, and co-founded the <a href="/wiki/Theosophical_Society" title="Theosophical Society">Theosophical Society</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-575"><a href="#cite_note-575">[565]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>, a major revolutionary, developed a variant of communism known as <a href="/wiki/Leninism" title="Leninism">Leninism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576"><a href="#cite_note-576">[566]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a>, on the other hand, founded <a href="/wiki/Trotskyism" title="Trotskyism">Trotskyism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[567]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Zinoviev" title="Alexander Zinoviev">Alexander Zinoviev</a> was a prominent philosopher in the second half of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[568]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Dugin" title="Aleksandr Dugin">Aleksandr Dugin</a>, known for his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fascist" title="Fascist">fascist</a> views, is the most notable Russian philosopher of the 21st century; being highly influential in Russian politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-579"><a href="#cite_note-579">[569]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russian_cuisine" title="Russian cuisine">Russian cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mint_bread_kvas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1971" data-file-width="2628" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/220px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/330px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/440px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mint_bread_kvas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kvass" title="Kvass">Kvass</a> is an ancient and traditional Russian beverage.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Russian_cuisine" title="Russian cuisine">Russian cuisine</a> has been formed by climate, cultural and religious traditions, and the vast geography of the nation; and it shares similarities with the cuisines of its neighbouring countries. Crops of <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">rye</a>, wheat, <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Millet" title="Millet">millet</a> provide the ingredients for various breads, <a href="/wiki/Pancake" title="Pancake">pancakes</a> and cereals, as well as for many drinks. <a href="/wiki/Bread_in_Europe#Finland_and_Russia" title="Bread in Europe">Bread</a>, of many varieties,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[570]</a></sup> is very popular across Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[571]</a></sup> Flavourful soups and stews include <a href="/wiki/Shchi" title="Shchi">shchi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Borsch" title="Borsch">borsch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukha" title="Ukha">ukha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solyanka" title="Solyanka">solyanka</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Okroshka" title="Okroshka">okroshka</a>. <a href="/wiki/Smetana_(dairy_product)" title="Smetana (dairy product)">Smetana</a> (a heavy <a href="/wiki/Sour_cream" title="Sour cream">sour cream</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Mayonnaise" title="Mayonnaise">mayonnaise</a> are often added to soups and salads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[572]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[573]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pirozhki" title="Pirozhki">Pirozhki</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[574]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Blini" title="Blini">blini</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[575]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Syrniki" title="Syrniki">syrniki</a> are native types of <a href="/wiki/Pancake" title="Pancake">pancakes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[576]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Beef_Stroganoff" title="Beef Stroganoff">Beef Stroganoff</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-the_art_587-0"><a href="#cite_note-the_art-587">[577]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 266">:â266â</span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chicken_Kiev" title="Chicken Kiev">Chicken Kiev</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-the_art_587-1"><a href="#cite_note-the_art-587">[577]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 320">:â320â</span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pelmeni" title="Pelmeni">pelmeni</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[578]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shashlyk" title="Shashlyk">shashlyk</a> are popular meat dishes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[579]</a></sup> Other meat dishes include stuffed cabbage rolls (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golubtsy" title="Golubtsy">golubtsy</a>) usually filled with meat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[580]</a></sup> Salads include <a href="/wiki/Olivier_salad" title="Olivier salad">Olivier salad</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591"><a href="#cite_note-591">[581]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vinegret" title="Vinegret">vinegret</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[582]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Dressed_herring" title="Dressed herring">dressed herring</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593"><a href="#cite_note-593">[583]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_drinks" title="List of national drinks">national non-alcoholic drink</a> is <a href="/wiki/Kvass" title="Kvass">kvass</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[584]</a></sup> and the national alcoholic drink is <a href="/wiki/Vodka" title="Vodka">vodka</a>; its creation in the nation dates back to the 14th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595"><a href="#cite_note-595">[585]</a></sup> The country has the world's highest vodka consumption,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[586]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Beer_in_Russia" title="Beer in Russia">beer</a> is the most popular alcoholic beverage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[587]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_wine" title="Russian wine">Wine</a> has become increasingly popular in Russia in the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[588]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_tea_consumption_per_capita" title="List of countries by tea consumption per capita">Tea has been popular in Russia</a> for centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-599"><a href="#cite_note-599">[589]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mass_media_and_cinema">Mass media and cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Russia" title="Media of Russia">Media of Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Russia" title="Cinema of Russia">Cinema of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4288" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg/170px-2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg/255px-2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg/340px-2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2019-07-28-3385-Moscow-Ostankino-Tower.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ostankino_Tower" title="Ostankino Tower">Ostankino Tower</a> in Moscow, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_freestanding_structures" title="List of tallest freestanding structures">tallest freestanding structure</a> in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600"><a href="#cite_note-600">[590]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>There are 400 news agencies in Russia, among which the largest internationally operating are <a href="/wiki/TASS" title="TASS">TASS</a>, <a href="/wiki/RIA_Novosti" title="RIA Novosti">RIA Novosti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_(news_agency)" title="Sputnik (news agency)">Sputnik</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Interfax" title="Interfax">Interfax</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mediaarchive_601-0"><a href="#cite_note-mediaarchive-601">[591]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Russia" title="Television in Russia">Television</a> is the most popular medium in Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcmedia_602-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbcmedia-602">[592]</a></sup> Among the 3,000 licensed radio stations nationwide, notable ones include <a href="/wiki/Radio_Rossii" title="Radio Rossii">Radio Rossii</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vesti_FM" title="Vesti FM">Vesti FM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Echo_of_Moscow" title="Echo of Moscow">Echo of Moscow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radio_Mayak" title="Radio Mayak">Radio Mayak</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russkoye_Radio" title="Russkoye Radio">Russkoye Radio</a>. Of the 16,000 registered newspapers, <a href="/wiki/Argumenty_i_Fakty" title="Argumenty i Fakty">Argumenty i Fakty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Komsomolskaya_Pravda" title="Komsomolskaya Pravda">Komsomolskaya Pravda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rossiyskaya_Gazeta" title="Rossiyskaya Gazeta">Rossiyskaya Gazeta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Izvestia" title="Izvestia">Izvestia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Moskovskij_Komsomolets" title="Moskovskij Komsomolets">Moskovskij Komsomolets</a> are popular. State-run <a href="/wiki/Channel_One_Russia" title="Channel One Russia">Channel One</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia-1" title="Russia-1">Russia-1</a> are the leading news channels, while <a href="/wiki/RT_(TV_network)" title="RT (TV network)">RT</a> is the flagship of Russia's international media operations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcmedia_602-1"><a href="#cite_note-bbcmedia-602">[592]</a></sup> Russia has the <a href="/wiki/Video_games_in_Russia" title="Video games in Russia">largest video gaming market</a> in Europe, with over 65 million players nationwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[593]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russian and later <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_cinema" title="Soviet cinema">Soviet cinema</a> was a hotbed of invention, resulting in world-renowned films such as <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Battleship_Potemkin" title="The Battleship Potemkin">The Battleship Potemkin</a></i>, which was named the <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best" title="List of films considered the best">greatest film of all time</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Expo_58" title="Expo 58">Brussels World's Fair</a> in 1958.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[594]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[595]</a></sup> Soviet-era filmmakers, most notably <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Eisenstein" title="Sergei Eisenstein">Sergei Eisenstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Tarkovsky" title="Andrei Tarkovsky">Andrei Tarkovsky</a>, would go on to become among of the world's most innovative and influential directors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[596]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[597]</a></sup> Eisenstein was a student of <a href="/wiki/Lev_Kuleshov" title="Lev Kuleshov">Lev Kuleshov</a>, who developed the groundbreaking <a href="/wiki/Soviet_montage_theory" title="Soviet montage theory">Soviet montage theory</a> of film editing at the world's first film school, the <a href="/wiki/Gerasimov_Institute_of_Cinematography" title="Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography">All-Union Institute of Cinematography</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[598]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dziga_Vertov" title="Dziga Vertov">Dziga Vertov</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Kino-Eye" title="Kino-Eye">Kino-Eye</a>" theory had a huge impact on the development of documentary filmmaking and cinema realism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[599]</a></sup> Many Soviet socialist realism films were artistically successful, including <i><a href="/wiki/Chapaev_(film)" title="Chapaev (film)">Chapaev</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cranes_Are_Flying" title="The Cranes Are Flying">The Cranes Are Flying</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Ballad_of_a_Soldier" title="Ballad of a Soldier">Ballad of a Soldier</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cinematic_489-1"><a href="#cite_note-cinematic-489">[479]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1960s and 1970s saw a greater variety of artistic styles in Soviet cinema.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cinematic_489-2"><a href="#cite_note-cinematic-489">[479]</a></sup> The comedies of <a href="/wiki/Eldar_Ryazanov" title="Eldar Ryazanov">Eldar Ryazanov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Gaidai" title="Leonid Gaidai">Leonid Gaidai</a> of that time were immensely popular, with many of the catchphrases still in use today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-610"><a href="#cite_note-610">[600]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-611"><a href="#cite_note-611">[601]</a></sup> In 1961â68 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sergey_Bondarchuk" title="Sergey Bondarchuk">Sergey Bondarchuk</a> directed an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award">Oscar</a>-winning <a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace_(film_series)" title="War and Peace (film series)">film adaptation</a> of Leo Tolstoy's epic <i><a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace" title="War and Peace">War and Peace</a></i>, which was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_most_expensive_film" title="The most expensive film">the most expensive film</a> made in the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cinematic_489-3"><a href="#cite_note-cinematic-489">[479]</a></sup> In 1969, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Motyl" title="Vladimir Motyl">Vladimir Motyl</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/White_Sun_of_the_Desert" title="White Sun of the Desert">White Sun of the Desert</a></i> was released, a very popular film in a genre of <a href="/wiki/Ostern" title="Ostern">ostern</a>; the film is traditionally watched by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cosmonauts" title="Cosmonauts">cosmonauts</a> before any trip into space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612"><a href="#cite_note-612">[602]</a></sup> After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the Russian cinema industry suffered large lossesâhowever, since the late 2000s, it has seen growth once again, and continues to expand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-613"><a href="#cite_note-613">[603]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Russia" title="Sport in Russia">Sport in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_(18405201199).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3287" data-file-width="4483" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg/220px-Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg/330px-Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg/440px-Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_(18405201199).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Maria_Sharapova" title="Maria Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a>, former <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_tennis_players" title="List of WTA number 1 ranked tennis players">world No. 1</a> tennis player, was the world's highest-paid female athlete for 11 consecutive years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-614"><a href="#cite_note-614">[604]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is the most popular sport in Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615"><a href="#cite_note-615">[605]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_football_team" title="Soviet Union national football team">Soviet Union national football team</a> became the first European champions by winning <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euro_1960" title="Euro 1960">Euro 1960</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-616"><a href="#cite_note-616">[606]</a></sup> and reached the finals of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euro_1988" title="Euro 1988">Euro 1988</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-617"><a href="#cite_note-617">[607]</a></sup> Russian clubs <a href="/wiki/PFC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PFC CSKA Moscow">CSKA Moscow</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zenit_Saint_Petersburg" title="Zenit Saint Petersburg">Zenit Saint Petersburg</a> won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UEFA_Cup" title="UEFA Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in 2005 and 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-618"><a href="#cite_note-618">[608]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-619"><a href="#cite_note-619">[609]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_national_football_team" title="Russian national football team">Russian national football team</a> reached the semi-finals of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euro_2008" title="Euro 2008">Euro 2008</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[610]</a></sup> Russia was the host nation for the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2017 FIFA Confederations Cup">2017 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621"><a href="#cite_note-621">[611]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[612]</a></sup> However, Russian teams are currently suspended from FIFA and UEFA competitions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623"><a href="#cite_note-623">[613]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey_in_Russia" title="Ice hockey in Russia">Ice hockey</a> is very popular in Russia, and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team" title="Soviet Union men's national ice hockey team">Soviet national ice hockey team</a> dominated the sport internationally throughout its existence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sport_487-1"><a href="#cite_note-sport-487">[477]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bandy" title="Bandy">Bandy</a> is Russia's national sport, and it has historically been the highest-achieving country in the sport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[614]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_national_basketball_team" title="Russian national basketball team">Russian national basketball team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2007" title="EuroBasket 2007">EuroBasket 2007</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[615]</a></sup> and the Russian basketball club <a href="/wiki/PBC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PBC CSKA Moscow">PBC CSKA Moscow</a> is among the most successful European basketball teams.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-626"><a href="#cite_note-626">[616]</a></sup> The annual <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> <a href="/wiki/Russian_Grand_Prix" title="Russian Grand Prix">Russian Grand Prix</a> was held at the <a href="/wiki/Sochi_Autodrom" title="Sochi Autodrom">Sochi Autodrom</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Sochi_Olympic_Park" title="Sochi Olympic Park">Sochi Olympic Park</a>, until its termination following the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-627"><a href="#cite_note-627">[617]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-628"><a href="#cite_note-628">[618]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, <a href="/wiki/Russia_at_the_Olympics" title="Russia at the Olympics">Russian athletes</a> have been one of the most successful contenders in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sport_487-2"><a href="#cite_note-sport-487">[477]</a></sup> Russia is the leading nation in <a href="/wiki/Rhythmic_gymnastics" title="Rhythmic gymnastics">rhythmic gymnastics</a>;
