and Russian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synchronised_swimming" title="Synchronised swimming">synchronised swimming</a> is considered to be the world's best.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-629"><a href="#cite_note-629">[619]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating" title="Figure skating">Figure skating</a> is another popular sport in Russia, especially <a href="/wiki/Pair_skating" title="Pair skating">pair skating</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ice_dancing" title="Ice dancing">ice dancing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-630"><a href="#cite_note-630">[620]</a></sup> Russia has produced numerous prominent tennis players.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-631"><a href="#cite_note-631">[621]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is also a widely popular pastime in the nation, with many of the world's top chess players being Russian for decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-632"><a href="#cite_note-632">[622]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympic_Games" title="1980 Summer Olympic Games">1980 Summer Olympic Games</a> were held in Moscow,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-633"><a href="#cite_note-633">[623]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Paralympics" title="2014 Winter Paralympics">2014 Winter Paralympics</a> were hosted in Sochi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634"><a href="#cite_note-634">[624]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-635"><a href="#cite_note-635">[625]</a></sup> However, Russia has also had 43 <a href="/wiki/Olympic_medal" title="Olympic medal">Olympic medals</a> stripped from its athletes due to <a href="/wiki/Doping_in_Russia" title="Doping in Russia">doping violations</a>, which is the most of any country, and nearly a third of the global total.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-636"><a href="#cite_note-636">[626]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox portalborder tright" role="navigation">

<li><span><img alt="flag" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="21" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/32px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/48px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/64px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" width="32"/></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Russia" title="Portal:Russia">Russia portal</a></span></li></ul></div>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Russia" title="Outline of Russia">Outline of Russia</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>, which was <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexed by Russia</a> in 2014, remains <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_68/262" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262">internationally recognised</a> as a part of Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dispute_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-dispute-1">[1]</a></sup> The southernmost <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kuril Islands</a> are also the subject of a territorial dispute with Japan since their occupation by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chapple-2019_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-chapple-2019-2">[2]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ArenaAtlasIslam-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlasIslam_6-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlasIslam_6-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">The Sreda Arena Atlas 2012 did not count the populations of two federal subjects of Russia where the majority of the population is Muslim, namely <a href="/wiki/Chechnya" title="Chechnya">Chechnya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ingushetia" title="Ingushetia">Ingushetia</a>, which together had a population of nearly 2 million, thus the proportion of Muslims was possibly slightly underestimated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_7-4"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-7">[5]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russian: <span title="Russian-language text"><span lang="ru">Ð Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸Ð¹ÑÐºÐ°Ñ Ð¤ÐµÐ´ÐµÑÐ°ÑÐ¸Ñ</span></span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">tr.</a></small> <span title="Russian-language text"><i lang="ru-Latn">Rossiyskaya Federatsiya</i></span>, <small>IPA:Â </small><span class="IPA" lang="ru-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">[rÉËsÊ²ijskÉjÉ fÊ²ÉªdÊ²ÉªËratsÉ¨jÉ]</a></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia shares land borders with fourteen <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sovereign_nation" title="Sovereign nation">sovereign nations</a>: <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> to the northwest; <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> to the west, as well as <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">Kaliningrad Oblast</a>); <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> to the southwest; <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a> to the south; China and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> to the southeast â as well as sharing <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime boundaries</a> with Japan and the United States. Russia also shares borders with the two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partially_recognized_states" title="Partially recognized states">partially recognised</a> breakaway states of <a href="/wiki/South_Ossetia" title="South Ossetia">South Ossetia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abkhazia" title="Abkhazia">Abkhazia</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-178"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-178">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Most notably the <a href="/wiki/Budyonnovsk_hospital_hostage_crisis" title="Budyonnovsk hospital hostage crisis">Budyonnovsk hospital hostage crisis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_apartment_bombings" title="Russian apartment bombings">Russian apartment bombings</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_theater_hostage_crisis" title="Moscow theater hostage crisis">Moscow theater hostage crisis</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Beslan_school_siege" title="Beslan school siege">Beslan school siege</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-203">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia has an additional 850Â km (530Â mi) of coastline along the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>, which is the world's largest inland body of water, and has been variously classified as a sea or a lake.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[197]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-206"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-206">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia, by land area, is larger than the continents of <a href="/wiki/Australia_(continent)" title="Australia (continent)">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, and Europe; although it covers a large part of the latter itself. Its land area could be roughly compared to that of South America.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-212"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-212">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia borders, clockwise, to its southwest: the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a>, to its west: the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, to its north: the <a href="/wiki/Barents_Sea" title="Barents Sea">Barents Sea</a> (<a href="/wiki/White_Sea" title="White Sea">White Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pechora_Sea" title="Pechora Sea">Pechora Sea</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Kara_Sea" title="Kara Sea">Kara Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Laptev_Sea" title="Laptev Sea">Laptev Sea</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Siberian_Sea" title="East Siberian Sea">East Siberian Sea</a>, to its northeast: the <a href="/wiki/Chukchi_Sea" title="Chukchi Sea">Chukchi Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bering_Sea" title="Bering Sea">Bering Sea</a>, and to its southeast: the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-241"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-241">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 2020, <a href="/wiki/2020_amendments_to_the_Constitution_of_Russia" title="2020 amendments to the Constitution of Russia">constitutional amendments</a> were signed into law that limit the president to two terms overall rather than two consecutive terms, with this limit reset for current and previous presidents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reformvote_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-reformvote-240">[232]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-249"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-249">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea" title="Republic of Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a>, and the federal city of <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>, which are disputed between Russia and Ukraine, since the internationally unrecognised annexation of Crimea in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dispute_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-dispute-1">[1]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist">
</div>

American Councils for International Education ACTR / ACCELS. <b>56</b>: 25â36. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/43669126" rel="nofollow">43669126</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Russian+Language+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Russian+as+the+National+Language%3A+An+Overview+of+Language+Planning+in+the+Russian+Federation&amp;rft.volume=56&amp;rft.pages=25-36&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F43669126%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Chevalier&amp;rft.aufirst=Joan+F.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-perepis-2010.ru-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-perepis-2010.ru_5-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120118212344/http://www.perepis-2010.ru/results_of_the_census/result-december-2011.ppt" rel="nofollow">"ÐÐÐ-2010"</a>. <i>perepis-2010.ru</i>. <li id="cite_note-IMFWEORU-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEORU_14-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEORU_14-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEORU_14-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEORU_14-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/weo-database/2022/April/weo-report?c=922,&amp;s=NGDPD,PPPGDP,NGDPDPC,PPPPC,&amp;sy=2020&amp;ey=2027&amp;ssm=0&amp;scsm=1&amp;scc=0&amp;ssd=1&amp;ssc=0&amp;sic=0&amp;sort=country&amp;ds=.&amp;br=1" rel="nofollow">"World Economic Outlook Database, April 2022"</a>. <i>IMF.org</i>. <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-WBgini-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-WBgini_15-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.GINI?locations=RU" rel="nofollow">"GINI index (World Bank estimate) â Russian Federation"</a>. <li id="cite_note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFDouka2019">Douka, K. <li id="cite_note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" <li id="cite_note-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-105">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFWalsh1928"><a href="/wiki/Edmund_A._Walsh" title="Edmund A. <li id="cite_note-160"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-160">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFShleiferVishny1991">Shleifer, Andrei; Vishny, Robert W. <li id="cite_note-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-172">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFShlapentokh2013">Shlapentokh, Vladimir (March 2013). <li id="cite_note-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-232">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFGrantham2020">Grantham HS,  etÂ al. <li id="cite_note-334"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-334">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFWadhams2022">Wadhams, Nick (8 March 2022). <a class="external text" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-07/russia-surges-past-iran-to-become-world-s-most-sanctioned-nation" rel="nofollow">"Russia Is Now the World's Most-Sanctioned Nation"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P." title="Bloomberg L.P.">Bloomberg L.P.</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate"> Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 October</span> 2022</span>. <q>Russia has vaulted past Iran and North Korea to become the world's most-sanctioned nation in the span of just 10 days following President Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bloomberg+L.P.&amp;rft.atitle=Russia+Is+Now+the+World%27s+Most-Sanctioned+Nation&amp;rft.date=2022-03-08&amp;rft.aulast=Wadhams&amp;rft.aufirst=Nick&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2Farticles%2F2022-03-07%2Frussia-surges-past-iran-to-become-world-s-most-sanctioned-nation&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-335"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-335">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFWhalenDixonNakashimaIlyushina2022">Whalen, Jeanne; Dixon, Robyn; Nakashima, Ellen; Ilyushina, Mary (23 August 2022). <a class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2022/08/23/russian-sanctions-economy/" rel="nofollow">"Western sanctions are wounding but not yet crushing Russia's economy"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 October</span> 2022</span>. <q>Russia has stopped publishing many economic statistics, making it difficult to judge how hard sanctions are hitting, but some data shows signs of distress.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Washington+Post&amp;rft.atitle=Western+sanctions+are+wounding+but+not+yet+crushing+Russia%27s+economy&amp;rft.date=2022-08-23&amp;rft.aulast=Whalen&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanne&amp;rft.au=Dixon%2C+Robyn&amp;rft.au=Nakashima%2C+Ellen&amp;rft.au=Ilyushina%2C+Mary&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fbusiness%2F2022%2F08%2F23%2Frussian-sanctions-economy%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-364"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-364">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.wilsoncenter.org/event/system-shock-russias-war-and-global-food-energy-and-mineral-supply-chains" rel="nofollow">"System Shock: Russia's War and Global Food, Energy, and Mineral Supply Chains"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson_International_Center_for_Scholars" title="Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars">Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars</a></i>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-climatechange-368"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-climatechange_368-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFLustgarten2020">Lustgarten, Abrahm (16 December 2020). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/12/16/magazine/russia-climate-migration-crisis.html" rel="nofollow">"How Russia Wins the Climate Crisis"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 June</span> 2021</span>. <q>Across Eastern Russia, wild forests, swamps and grasslands are slowly being transformed into orderly grids of soybeans, corn and wheat. Itâs a process that is likely to accelerate: Russia hopes to seize on the warming temperatures and longer growing seasons brought by climate change to refashion itself as one of the planetâs largest producers of food</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=How+Russia+Wins+the+Climate+Crisis&amp;rft.date=2020-12-16&amp;rft.aulast=Lustgarten&amp;rft.aufirst=Abrahm&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2Finteractive%2F2020%2F12%2F16%2Fmagazine%2Frussia-climate-migration-crisis.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-380"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-380">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFShampoKyleSteensma2012">Shampo, Marc A.; Kyle, Robert A.; Steensma, David P. <li id="cite_note-403"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-403">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPerminov1999">Perminov, V.G. <li id="cite_note-405"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-405">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nasa.gov/feature/50-years-ago-launch-of-salyut-the-world-s-first-space-station" rel="nofollow">"50 Years Ago: Launch of Salyut, the World's First Space Station"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/NASA_Space_Science_Data_Coordinated_Archive" title="NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive">NSSDCA</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a>. 19 April 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-2010Census-417"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2010Census_417-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFRussian_Federal_State_Statistics_Service2011">Russian Federal State Statistics Service (2011). <a class="external text" href="http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/croc/perepis_itogi1612.htm" rel="nofollow"><bdi lang="ru">ÐÑÐµÑÐ¾ÑÑÐ¸Ð¹ÑÐºÐ°Ñ Ð¿ÐµÑÐµÐ¿Ð¸ÑÑ Ð½Ð°ÑÐµÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ 2010 Ð³Ð¾Ð´Ð°. Ð¢Ð¾Ð¼Â 1</bdi></a> [2010 All-Russian Population Census, vol.Â 1].  <bdi lang="ru">ÐÑÐµÑÐ¾ÑÑÐ¸Ð¹ÑÐºÐ°Ñ Ð¿ÐµÑÐµÐ¿Ð¸ÑÑ Ð½Ð°ÑÐµÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ 2010Â Ð³Ð¾Ð´Ð° [2010 All-Russia Population Census]</bdi> (in Russian). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Federal_State_Statistics_Service" title="Russian Federal State Statistics Service">Federal State Statistics Service</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%D0%92%D1%81%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F+%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%8C+%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F+2010+%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0.+%D0%A2%D0%BE%D0%BC+1&amp;rft.pub=Federal+State+Statistics+Service&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.au=Russian+Federal+State+Statistics+Service&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gks.ru%2Ffree_doc%2Fnew_site%2Fperepis2010%2Fcroc%2Fperepis_itogi1612.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-422"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-422">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFFoltynova2020">Foltynova, Kristyna (19 June 2020). <a class="external text" href="https://www.rferl.org/a/migrants-welcome-is-russia-trying-to-solve-its-demographic-crisis-by-attracting-foreigners-/30677952.html" rel="nofollow">"Migrants Welcome: Is Russia Trying To Solve Its Demographic Crisis By Attracting Foreigners?"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Radio_Free_Europe/Radio_Liberty" title="Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty">Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">9 July</span> 2021</span>. <q>Russia has been trying to boost fertility rates and reduce death rates for several years now. Special programs for families have been implemented, anti-tobacco campaigns have been organized, and raising the legal age to buy alcohol was considered. However, perhaps the most successful strategy so far has been attracting migrants, whose arrival helps Russia to compensate population losses.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Migrants+Welcome%3A+Is+Russia+Trying+To+Solve+Its+Demographic+Crisis+By+Attracting+Foreigners%3F&amp;rft.pub=Radio+Free+Europe%2FRadio+Liberty&amp;rft.date=2020-06-19&amp;rft.aulast=Foltynova&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristyna&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.rferl.org%2Fa%2Fmigrants-welcome-is-russia-trying-to-solve-its-demographic-crisis-by-attracting-foreigners-%2F30677952.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-431"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-431">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFKirk2016">Kirk, Ashley (21 January 2016). <span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a class="external text" href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/12111108/Mapped-Which-country-has-the-most-immigrants.html" rel="nofollow">"Mapped: Which country has the most immigrants?"</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a></i>. <a class="external text" href="https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/12111108/Mapped-Which-country-has-the-most-immigrants.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 10 January 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-434"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-434">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLazarevPravikova">Lazarev, Vladimir; Pravikova, Ludmila. <a class="external text" href="http://www.lingref.com/isb/4/103ISB4.PDF" rel="nofollow">"The North Caucasus Bilingualism and Language Identity"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <li id="cite_note-440"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-440">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-04.htm" rel="nofollow">"Chapter 3. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">27 December</span> 2007</span>. <q>2. The Republics shall have the right to establish their own state languages. In the bodies of state authority and local self-government, state institutions of the Republics they shall be used together with the state language of the Russian Federation. 3. The Russian Federation shall guarantee to all of its peoples the right to preserve their native language and to create conditions for its study and development.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Chapter+3.+The+Federal+Structure&amp;rft.pub=Constitution+of+Russia&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.constitution.ru%2Fen%2F10003000-04.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-454"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-454">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMenzelHagemeisterGlatzer_Rosenthal2012">Menzel, Brigit; Hagemeister, Michael; Glatzer Rosenthal, Bernice, eds. <li id="cite_note-478"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-478">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFThe_Lancet2019">The Lancet (5 October 2019). <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1016%2FS0140-6736%2819%2932265-2" rel="nofollow">"Russia's alcohol policy: a continuing success story"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lancet" title="The Lancet">The Lancet</a></i>. <b>394</b> (10205): 1205. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1016%2FS0140-6736%2819%2932265-2" rel="nofollow">10.1016/S0140-6736(19)32265-2</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31591968" rel="nofollow">31591968</a>. <q>Russians are officially drinking less and, as a consequence, are living longer than ever before...Russians are still far from being teetotal: a pure ethanol per capita consumption of 11Â·7 L, reported in 2016, means consumption is still one of the highest worldwide, and efforts to reduce it further are required.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Lancet&amp;rft.atitle=Russia%27s+alcohol+policy%3A+a+continuing+success+story&amp;rft.volume=394&amp;rft.issue=10205&amp;rft.pages=1205&amp;rft.date=2019-10-05&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1016%2FS0140-6736%2819%2932265-2&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F31591968&amp;rft.au=The+Lancet&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1016%252FS0140-6736%252819%252932265-2&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-482"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-482">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLincoln1970">Lincoln, W.B. <li id="cite_note-494"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-494">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRiabov2020">Riabov, Oleg (2020). <li id="cite_note-536"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-536">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1">"David Oistrakh". <i><a href="/wiki/The_Musical_Times" title="The Musical Times">The Musical Times</a></i>. <b>115</b> (1582): 1071. <li id="cite_note-576"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-576">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBrinkley1998">Brinkley, George (1998). <li>Frye, Timothy. <i>Weak Strongman: The Limits of Power in Putin's Russia</i> (2021) <a class="external text" href="https://www.amazon.com/Weak-Strongman-Limits-Putins-Russia/dp/0691212465/" rel="nofollow">excerpt</a></li>
<li>Greene, by Samuel A. and Graeme B. Robertson. <i>Putin v. the People: the Perilous Politics of a Divided Russia</i> (Yale UP, 2019) <a class="external text" href="https://www.amazon.com/Putin-v-People-Perilous-Politics/dp/0300238398/" rel="nofollow">excerpt</a></li>

<li>Kort, Michael. <i>A Brief History of Russia</i> (2008) <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/briefhistoryofru0000kort" rel="nofollow">online</a></li>

</div></td><td class="noviewer navbox-image" rowspan="4" style="width:1px;padding:0 0 0 2px"><div><a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe"><img alt="Europe orthographic Caucasus Urals boundary (with borders).svg" data-file-height="536" data-file-width="537" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Europe_orthographic_Caucasus_Urals_boundary_%28with_borders%29.svg/100px-Europe_orthographic_Caucasus_Urals_boundary_%28with_borders%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Europe_orthographic_Caucasus_Urals_boundary_%28with_borders%29.svg/150px-Europe_orthographic_Caucasus_Urals_boundary_%28with_borders%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Europe_orthographic_Caucasus_Urals_boundary_%28with_borders%29.svg/200px-Europe_orthographic_Caucasus_Urals_boundary_%28with_borders%29.svg.png 2x" width="100"/></a></div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;"><a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">States with limited<br/>recognition</a></div></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3"><div><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><sup>1</sup> Spans the conventional boundary between Europe and another continent.</li><li><sup>2</sup> Considered European for cultural, political and historical reasons but is geographically in Western Asia.</li><li><sup>3</sup> <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">Oceanic islands</a> within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.</li></ul></div>

<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation_(SCO)" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible mw-collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Template:Shanghai Cooperation Organisation"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Template talk:Shanghai Cooperation Organisation"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation_(SCO)" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO)</a></div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Summits</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/2012_SCO_summit" title="2012 SCO summit">Beijing 2012</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/2014_SCO_summit" title="2014 SCO summit">Dushanbe 2014</a></li>
